PART FOUR

The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Life</span> of Trees

13. The Role of the Forest
When someone dies the bell tolls. When the forest dies and with it a
<span class="t3 t5 t7 t9 t20 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> people, then no-one lifts a finger.
Viktor Schauberger1
Only <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> who <span class="t7 hoverable">love</span> it should care for the forest. Those who view the
forest merely as an object of speculation do it and all other living
creatures <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> harm, for the forest is the cradle of water. If the forest
dies, then the springs will dry up, the meadows will <span class="t8 t13 hoverable">become</span> barren
and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> countries will inevitably be seized by unrest of such a kind
that it will bode ill for <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">every</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> of us.
Viktor Schauberger2
Viktor Schauberger, who believed that the <span class="t6 t9 t22 t29 hoverable">highest</span> quality <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span>
depends on the forest, predicted that deforestation <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> <span class="t22 hoverable">bring</span>
<span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> shortage and climate change. As equatorial deforestation has
greatly accelerated since he died, it <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t18 t21 t22 t23 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">might</span> be useful to summarize
the effects of this devastation.

Evolution of the forest
Plants have been around for 420 million years, which is only 9% of
Earth's history. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Without</span> plants there <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> be no life, for plants are
the essential link for converting the Suns energy into food. Trees are
the <span class="t6 t9 t22 t29 hoverable">highest</span> <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of the plant, and the most efficient exchangers of
energy between the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Earth</span> and the Sun. The forests are the main
source of oxygen, an essential building block of life; they are the
Earth's 'lungs.' There have been <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> periods when forests have
flourished: in the Carboniferous Age 350 million <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> ago, when
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 hoverable">land</span> vertebrates became established; in the Eocene, 60 million <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span>
ago, when primitive mammals <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> appeared, and in the last
500,000 years, when the cultures of modern <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> developed. It
seems that in each case a boost in the oxygen content of the atmosphere, which the forests delivered, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> have been the trigger for
evolutionary explosion of Earth's <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> forms.
These extensive forests developed in the equatorial regions
where the heat was available to prime a remarkable engine for moderating the extremes of temperature and the often chaotic <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of
13. THE ROLE OF THE FOREST

the world's historical climate. In the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> case they were evergreen
forests, interspersed with enormous swamps. In the Eocene when
the modern <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> mountain ranges were being uplifted, there were
large tropical jungles, perhaps not too <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> from the modern
ones which flourished on all the continents until the late nineteenth
century, but with less complex fauna.
It is interesting to speculate what caused the forests to establish
themselves at these periods. Viktor Schauberger recognized <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span>
as an intelligent system endowed with <span class="t6 t13 t14 t25 t27 hoverable">meaning</span> and purpose that is
concerned with evolving more complex life-forms and a higher level
of consciousness. From that perspective it is possible that the establishment of forest <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t18 t21 t22 t23 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">might</span> be seen as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of that purpose.
Forest cover varies with climate. Forests have been the natural
cover of perhaps <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> quarters of the Earth's <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 hoverable">land</span> surface during
these periods of evolutionary expansion. This natural forest was an
essential prerequisite for the development of the extraordinarily
rich variety of fauna and flora (now <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> 'biodiversity') that makes
this planet an important source of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> in the Universe.

Destruction of the forests
Either fortuitously or by design, there seems to be a large degree of
tolerance in Earth's ecosystems for the amount of forest cover
required to support a balanced climate — <span class="t0 t1 t2 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> what a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span>
reduction of forest does to biodiversity and the quality of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> is
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">another</span> question. Over the half a million or so <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> of humankind's
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> on Earth, our species has been responsible for reduction of the
forest cover to about 25% of its optimum extent. The early agriculturists <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> burn clearings to grow their crops, and then move on
to allow the fertility to be replenished. Early civilizations, some <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t8 t10 t12 t13 t14 t17 t19 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">well</span>
documented and some which are now folk memories, felled vast
tracts of forest.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Many</span> of these lands became desertified, such as the Gobi, Sind,
Arabian, Mesopotamian, North African and Kalahari deserts —
probably through a combination of deforestation and climate
change. <span class="t3 t5 t7 t9 t20 t28 t29 hoverable">Whole</span> nations were uprooted and had to move elsewhere in
their search for subsistence. The same is likely to happen today
where <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> swathes of the rich equatorial forests have been cleared.
Fortunately in those <span class="t0 t3 t4 t5 t11 t20 t26 t27 hoverable">days</span> there was somewhere else for the displaced to go, because the world's population was still relatively
HIDDEN <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span>

small. Today, however, because of overpopulation and an unsustainable birth rate, any climate changes that produce crop failures can
mean only starvation and the loss of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> through conflict. In temperate climates, clear felling of forests does not normally lead to
desertification, but it affects the biodiversity, the fertility and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> the long-term health of the environment.
Ten thousand <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> ago the <span class="t3 t5 t7 t9 t20 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> Mediterranean region was
covered with forests, mainly of oak. Then about 5,000 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> ago the
forests of Lebanon provided the timber for the Phoenician empire.
We don't <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">know</span> what happened to the forests of North Africa, but <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span>
thousand <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> ago these lands were so fertile that the Romans
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> them the breadbasket of the Mediterranean. They are now
arid desert. A thousand <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> ago 80% of Europe was forested; today
it is about 20%, <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> of which is monocultured industrial woodland, which lacks the biodiversity and the energy of natural forest.
In North America, the forest extended from the Atlantic to beyond
the Mississippi, and of course west of the Rockies.
Sometimes the forests were exploited to provide fast economic
expansion, regardless of the cost to future generations. In <span class="t0 t6 t7 t8 t11 t13 t14 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">order</span> to
provide a navy capable of ruling the seas, in the early sixteenth century Henry <span class="t6 t14 t27 hoverable">VIII</span> ordered the felling of a million mature oak trees,
virtually denuding England of its mature oaks. The world's forest
cover was reduced from about 75% at its greatest to about 50% in
medieval times. By 1900 it had dropped to about 35%. In the frantic rush to get rich quick, regardless of the consequences, the figure
has dropped to 25% and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">every</span> year we are still losing equatorial forest the size of Belgium.
Today, the unstable social conditions worldwide, and irresponsible political leadership favour greedy opportunists anxious to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">make</span>
their fortunes, often illegally, by logging <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> of the finest stands of
prime forests on <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">every</span> continent. This destruction is likely to be
seen in the future as dangerous planetary vandalism, because their
consequences will bear heavily on the future global environmental
balance.

A moral tale
Easter Island, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> of the most remote islands in the Pacific Ocean,
was occupied by a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> about whom we <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">know</span> little, but who had
the most remarkable artistic skills (witness the giant statues they
13. THE ROLE OF THE FOREST

left behind), and a sophisticated culture. It had a cover of forest, fertile soil, and at <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> supported over 20,000 people. Towards the
<span class="t7 t10 t15 t25 hoverable">end</span> of the thousand <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> of their occupation of the island, their
society clearly deteriorated and they had felled all the trees, so that
by AD500, there was no <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> to build a boat and leave the island. The
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> literally died out.
Of all the violations we have committed against the beautiful
and fertile planet we call home, the destruction of the forests is the
hardest to comprehend. The effects of such actions are so quickly
apparent, in terms of soil depletion, or in extreme cases, of erosion
of the living soil layer by rain or wind, and indeed, through climate
change. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> floods of the Rhine in recent years, and the devastating floods in Bangladesh and the mud slides in Assam and
Honduras have been caused demonstrably by deforestation in the
mountains. In spite of this, the tree felling continues. When the
European immigrants settled in North America, there was continuous forest from the Atlantic to the Mississippi.
Five thousand <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> earlier the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> Midwestern prairies and
the grasslands of Argentina were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> forested. The deep soils of the
temperate latitudes were created over hundreds of thousands of
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> by rich natural forest. (Grasslands do not produce deep soils.)
And <span class="t5 t7 hoverable">within</span> a hundred <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> we have ruined these, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> by intensive
cultivation, and then by chemical poisoning. The American prairies,
and the East Anglian wheat fields have lost on average half their soil
depth. When in 1999, over 30,000 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> died in mudslides in
Venezuela, scientists blamed the weather! The obvious lessons are
not being learned, which suggests that our 'experts' are completely
out of touch with reality, a complaint frequently voiced by Viktor
Schauberger!
We are told that the critical point <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> soon be reached when
there will not be enough forest to produce sufficient oxygen to support high quality life. For the forests are the lungs of the Earth,
breathing in carbon dioxide (CO2) and exhaling oxygen (O). When
the trees are felled, and again when they are burned, they contribute
to the mass of carbon dioxide, the principal global warming gas.
Recent analyses of fossilized amber have shown that their air bubbles contained 38% oxygen. Today the average oxygen content of air
is 19%, which suggests that the <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> was designed to operate at twice today's concentration of oxygen. In some larger cities
the oxygen content has deteriorated to as low as 12%.
HIDDEN <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span>

Crucially, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> still little understood, forests create the environment for the propagation of water, the 'first-born' of the energies
of life, as Schauberger puts it, and they moderate the climate, making it cooler in summer and warmer in winter. They are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> responsible for the mineralization and fertilization of the surface soils,
essential for the nutrition of higher <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> forms and, most important
of all, the forests create the rich humus and bacterial life, the foundation of a rich biodiversity, which stores and recycles vast amounts
of rainfall, preventing floods on lower land.3

Tropical rainforests
Everyone who has the opportunity, before it is too late, should visit
a tropical rainforest, for they are the priceless jewels of our ecosystem. Important not just for the incredible richness and variety of
their fauna and flora, they have had a substantially modifying influence on the world's climate, helping to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">make</span> most of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Earth</span>
pleasantly habitable and very productive. They were on four continents, but are now only about half their extent of 500 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> ago: the
South American is the most complete, at about 75% of its original
size; the South-east Asian, from India, through Indo-China to
Indonesia and Australia is about a third of what it was, and the
African about 40% of its original size. The Central American has
virtually disappeared.
More than twice as <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> of the Sun's energy reaches the Earth's
surface at the tropics as in high latitudes where the Sun's angle
above the horizon is very low. The tropical rainforests of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span>
act as heat pumps, transferring to higher latitudes some of the enormous energy they generate, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> evening out the temperature difference. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Without</span> them, the equatorial regions <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> hotter,
and the higher latitudes <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> colder. The larger the mass of a tropical rainforest, the more effective it is as a heat pump.
Now that we know, from a study of the Amazonian rainforest,
how the heat pump works, it is possible to conjecture that the
African continent <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> not have been nearly as dry as it is today.
In South-East Asia the destruction has reached cataclysmic proportions, with a free-for-all between corrupt local interests and greedy
multinational companies who are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> extracting minerals at a fast
pace, particularly in Borneo, where most of the virgin forests, theoretically protected, are likely to disappear <span class="t5 t7 hoverable">within</span> fifteen years.

Fig. 13.1. The Amazon heat engine and the North Atlantic.
The Amazon Basin is the big heat engine that controls the climate of the Northern Hemisphere, but only when the tropical rainforest is largely

Greenland icecap. <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t8 t9 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Note</span> 13.7 explains how the Amazonian heat engine works.

Within the last decade both droughts and storms have, for example
in Australia, <span class="t8 t13 hoverable">become</span> consistently more severe. With the accelerated
destruction of the forest, the climatic future of the region looks
grim. Amazonia contains two-thirds of the world's surviving tropical rainforest, representing about 30% of all the biological material
on the land.4 You can imagine that when all four tropical rain forests
were intact, they <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">must</span> have contained the greater <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the plant
and animal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> on Earth.
The released energy drives the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> air masses across the
Amazon basin to the Andes, recycling the rain and evapo-transpiration several times in a leapfrogging process (see Fig. 13.1).
The airflow then splits into three: the southern <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> is deflected
as <span class="t6 t9 t18 t26 hoverable">far</span> as Patagonia; the central <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> flows over the Andes into the
Pacific, continuing west as the trade winds; the northern airflow
crosses the Caribbean, and helps to drive the Gulf Stream northeastwards to Europe.6 Rainforests act as thermal engines, rainfall
stimulators and as regulators of atmospheric and oceanic systems. They moderate the climate of the <span class="t3 t5 t7 t9 t20 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Earth</span> and help to
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">make</span> it habitable.
The Amazon Basin, which comprises 7 million km2 of rainforest, is the biggest and most efficient energy transformer on Earth7;
it is self-maintaining when complete, but 25% has already been
lost in the last 35 years. Five million km2 lie in Brazil which has
recently unveiled an accelerated development plan (see below)
that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> result in the loss of a further 20% by 2020 (a total loss
of forest of 45%!). There is a critical size of the Amazonian rainforest below which this complex heat engine and rainfall distributor will fail. Some authorities claim that if it shrinks to <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> less
than the present 75% of its original area, the forest will not be able
to perform these critical functions effectively, resulting in more
hostile weather patterns and drought across the globe.8
Areas that have been clear-felled <span class="t0 t2 t16 t18 t21 t22 t23 hoverable">put</span> at risk the remaining forest
for <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> miles from the edge of the deforested area, rendering the
marginal area more susceptible to die-back due to the local increase
in temperature. In fact, the Amazonian forest through deforestation
is generally losing its ability to withstand the worldwide temperature increase created by global warming. At some point, perhaps in
the next twenty <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> (or sooner under present Brazilian plan), a
critical point <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> be reached, when massive die-back <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> <span class="t1 t3 t9 t15 t20 t21 t26 t29 hoverable">cause</span>
this vital energy transformer to fail.
13. THE ROLE OF THE FOREST

Preservation of this precious forest is a tough battle. In June
2000, the biggest landowners in Brazil who control 50% of the agricultural land, pushed a draft <span class="t0 t8 t12 t15 t19 t23 t25 hoverable">law</span> through the Brazilian senate committee which <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> have allowed a 25% increase in annual rates of
clearing and burning of the forest. An international email campaign
amongst environmentalists, instantly mounted, generated hundreds of thousands of signatures, forcing the Congress to back
down. Less than a year later however, the Brazilian government
launched the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> more ambitious Avanca Brasil plan to develop
most of Amazonia, with <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> highways, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> railroads; <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> settlements and extraction of minerals and timber. The <span class="t3 t5 t7 t9 t20 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> region will
be transformed in the next twenty years, with the remains of the
forest chopped into strips and blocks with little chance of survival.
This unbelievably irresponsible policy can be stopped only by mass
international protest.

Forestry
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">death</span> of the forests is only the tip of the iceberg and is a reflection
of the deeper deterioration in humankind itself
Ernst Krebs
If a forest's climate changes over hundreds or thousands of years,
the types of trees that grow in it will gradually change, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span>
threatening the survival of the forest. However, if the rate of climate
change accelerates, as it is doing today, <span class="t3 hoverable">certain</span> species disappear
before <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> species can <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">take</span> hold. The forest starts to lose its vitality and will gradually deteriorate into an arid wasteland.
The modern science of forestry began in the early nineteenth century. Napoleon in his passage over the Alps removed an unbelievable
number of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> trees, and the Swiss were determined to restore the
damage. Less concerned with mass production than we are today,
they insisted that planting <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">must</span> be of appropriate species. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Though</span>
this sensitivity to landscape and the environment is still practised in
Switzerland and Austria, in other countries forestry has deteriorated
to the production of timber for cheap furniture, chipboard and firewood, as that is about all the poor quality of timber is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> for.
Forestry today is about planting single species' woodland to be
harvested <span class="t5 t7 hoverable">within</span> as short a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> as possible (while the trees are
mere adolescents) in <span class="t0 t6 t7 t8 t11 t13 t14 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">order</span> to maximize the profit. A redwood for
HIDDEN <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span>

example, which has a lifespan of 2000 years, today is harvested after
sixty years, before it can be fruitful, at about 3% of its potential.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Without</span> mature seed, the genetic base of the remaining seed has
deteriorated to the point of infertility. The consequences of this
madness are far-reaching, for as the biological diversity is depleted
of its <span class="t6 t9 t22 t29 hoverable">highest</span> quality organisms, so too are the energies that support
higher forms of life. The destruction of the forest brings with it the
destruction of water, with appalling consequences.

Monoculture
If you go into a typical plantation, it is impenetrable, dark, and feels
dead — a veritable green desert. No birds sing nor animals scurry,
and there is little opportunity for any other plants to grow. Those
that do are removed on the theory that they <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">take</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">away</span> nourishment
from the trees. In fact their absence increases the competition. The
individual trees are all of the same age and species; they vie with
each other for space and for nutrients (of which there is a limited
amount for each species), for their roots go down to the same level,
creating a hard pan of salts which prevents access to the valuable
minerals and energized groundwater below. There is only a <span class="t3 hoverable">certain</span>
amount of each element and chemical compound available which is
suitable for that species and all the trees <span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whose</span> lives are wholly
dependent on them <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">must</span> fight to get it.
It is hardly surprising that the wood from such a plantation is
of very poor quality. You <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t18 t21 t22 t23 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">might</span> compare the composition of a
<span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> community to a forest. If all the individual humans were
clones of each other, and there were no elder statesmen or wise
elders, how creatively barren and spiritually impoverished <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span>
be that community! These young trees are clear-felled, leaving a
scene of devastation, with the valuable soil vulnerable to erosion.
Students of forestry do not <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> learn the purpose of a natural forest, nor about biodiversity, which is the keystone of Nature's
order.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Without</span> natural forest, higher forms of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> on this planet <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span>
not have been able to develop. Apart from oxygenating the atmosphere and replenishing the water, both of which sustain life, it contains the vital pyramid of the <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> levels of life, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> which
<span class="t14 hoverable">creation</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> degenerate, as it is doing in our time. By a mysterious process, forests encourage rainfall; appropriate trees planted in
13. THE ROLE OF THE FOREST

an arid or desert environment devoid of rainfall will often <span class="t1 t3 t9 t15 t20 t21 t26 t29 hoverable">cause</span>
rain to fall, nourishing the trees, and starting the process of healing
that environment.

Biodiversity
A natural, undisturbed forest has a rich diversity in colour and <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span>
that brings a sense of inner tranquillity and peace. With our warped
sense of <span class="t0 t6 t7 t8 t11 t13 t14 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">order</span> we <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">see</span> the profusion of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> as chaotic, whereas in fact
it is in the <span class="t6 t9 t22 t29 hoverable">highest</span> state of order. <span class="t0 t6 t7 t8 t11 t13 t14 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">Order</span> in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> arises from a sensitive state of balance in a highly complex ecosystem. What we often
recognize as ordered is usually sterile and uniform.
The natural forest is a community of vast numbers of species of
plants, animals and micro-organisms which <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">cannot</span> flourish or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span>
survive <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> each other. This interdependence is something we
still little understand, and the tragedy is that, with the disappearance of the tropical rainforests, we <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">shall</span> lose the vital laboratory that
is the most complex ecosystem on Earth. They contain literally millions of species of fauna and flora, most of which we have not <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span>
been able to study. Science does not <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> fully understand either the
full importance of biodiversity, nor how it is achieved, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> its preservation is essential to our salvation. There is a rapidly decreasing
number of places in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> to study it, and they are hastily being
converted to monoculture or to arable land, the exterminators of
biodiversity.
The rainforest has <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> layers of trees and shrubs, the high
trees, the overstorey, protecting those below that need shade. The
trees with deep root systems <span class="t22 hoverable">bring</span> up valuable minerals and nutrients from below, beyond the reach of the more shallow-rooted. The
micro-organisms on the forest floor thrive on the rich variety of
leaves and provide valuable nourishment for all the plants.
The ground remains cool and moist due to the protection of the
trees overhead and the rich spongy humus can retain up to 85% of
the rain, which recharges the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> table and allows the full circulation of groundwater. This essential element of the natural forest is
an early victim to deforestation for, when exposed to the elements,
the ground surface quickly deteriorates, its ability to hold <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span>
compromised — for warm ground sheds the rain <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> concrete —
which results in floods in the lands below.
The trees that grow the tallest, or on the outer edge of the forest
HIDDEN <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span>

are equipped to withstand the heat and direct sunlight. They in turn
protect those that are more delicate and light-sensitive, and the
young trees that need the CO2-rich environment and coolness of the
lower layers of the forest.
Those trees and shrubs that are sensitive to <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> and heat are
shielded from degenerative effects by varieties of tree <span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whose</span> structure is designed to resist the heating. By the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> the mother tree
dies, its young are ready to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">take</span> over the role of their parents.
Because trees are allowed to mature and live out their full cycle,
their seeds are of the <span class="t6 t9 t22 t29 hoverable">highest</span> quality, which ensures that the forest
stays in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> heart. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> here, with this rich variety, is in a productive state of balance, what Schauberger calls 'changeable, unstable equilibrium.'
Clearly only Nature, <span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whose</span> very foundation is interconnectedness, can truly create biodiversity, albeit slowly. Humanity, now the
dominant species, if it is to survive, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">must</span> replace its present methods of cultivation, for forestry or food, with radically <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> methods that are sustainable. The most promising experiments to this
<span class="t7 t10 t15 t25 hoverable">end</span> have been <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> by Permaculture, an environmental movement
founded by Bill Mollison and <span class="t4 t22 hoverable">David</span> Holmgren in Australia in 1974.9
They have demonstrated how to create an integrated environment
of plants that grow best in association with <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> another, protecting
each other from pests.
In these artificially created natural habitats, horticulture,
forestry and animal husbandry are combined into a harmonious
and sustainable whole. Shelter belts of trees are planted to protect
the cultivated plots. The available water, the microclimate and the
soil conditions are <span class="t19 hoverable">taken</span> into account. Each <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> community is
in this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> able gradually to <span class="t8 t13 hoverable">become</span> more self-sufficient. Permaculture methods have been introduced, with <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> success, into countries <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> India where the levels of poverty often restrict the ability
of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> to feed themselves. Natural methods of composting and
fertilization are <span class="t27 hoverable">used</span> instead of artificial fertilizers.
High quality hardwoods are still coming out of equatorial and temperate forests and <span class="t27 hoverable">used</span> for fine furniture and musical instruments.
Soon these resources will be exhausted. Where else are we to find
such fine wood? Since mass production has <span class="t8 t13 hoverable">become</span> the norm,
understanding has been lost of the natural processes required to
produce high-quality timber. Vast areas of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 hoverable">land</span> are cleared of trees
13. THE ROLE OF THE FOREST

completely, exposing the soil to the direct heat and <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of the Sun.
This raises the ground temperatures, the delicate soil-capillaries are
destroyed which deliver nutrients and moisture to the soil — and
the groundwater table sinks. Hardwoods will not be <span class="t27 hoverable">used</span> in the
replanting, as they require too <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> to mature for commercial
exploitation. Reforestation is generally of softwoods such as pine,
for contemporary forestry is not interested in quality or in longterm investment.

Energy in the forest
The Sun's energy reaches the Earth's surface as a full spectrum of
<span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> waves. In a natural, mixed forest, this energy is transformed
into creative growth, the various plants absorbing <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> parts
of the spectrum. The outcome of this is the production of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span>
water, a humus layer teeming with bacterial <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> (which is an efficient counter to pollution), and an overall coolness and feeling of
harmony. In Nature, a function that maintains any system (e.g. a
forest) in a state of stable health and balance is the outer expression of an inner creative force. It is significant that medicinal
plants will grow only in a healthy forest where the biodiversity is
greatest.
A monocultured woodland, on the other hand, absorbs only a
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> spectrum, the balance being <span class="t1 t2 t4 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">given</span> off as ambient
heat. The Sun's energy is provided to create balanced <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> forms. If
it <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">cannot</span> fulfil its creative functions, it becomes destructive, in
this case overheating the monocultured trees. The energies are not
balanced, and this discord affects all the creatures. The pulsation
and harmonious interaction of the energies are disrupted, encouraging disease and disharmony. Schauberger showed that highly
ordered and diverse systems lose their stability when their environment suffers deterioration, indicating that we <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> expect
moral and <span class="t7 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">spiritual</span> deterioration in the <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> community.
In the <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> a blood temperature of 37°C (98.4°F) is
regarded as being healthy. Should it rise to 38.5°C (103.1°F), symptoms of distress are felt and we <span class="t8 t13 hoverable">become</span> susceptible to infection by
life-forms that are normally dormant in the body, but which
<span class="t8 t13 hoverable">become</span> activated between, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">say</span> 38.2°C (100.6°F) and 38.6°C
(101°F). The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> will usually respond with a fever, which drives
the temperature higher, destroying the bacteria or virus that
HIDDEN <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span>

brought the infection. Schauberger <span class="t0 t16 t25 t28 hoverable">found</span> that it is the same with
trees. Their health is stable <span class="t5 t7 hoverable">within</span> a narrow range. When a tree
becomes overheated, it becomes susceptible to parasites and fungal
attack. It is not the parasites that <span class="t1 t3 t9 t15 t20 t21 t26 t29 hoverable">cause</span> the sickness, but the changes
in temperature and energy balance.

13. THE ROLE OF THE FOREST

14. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Life</span> and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> of Trees
Trees in the biosphere
Humans have always had a very close interdependence with trees.1
Hominids <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">came</span> on the scene at <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> of those rarer times in Earth's
history when a forest environment predominated. For the greater
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of our short <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> on the planet, our ancestors grew up <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span>
trees. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">First</span> they <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> slash and burn small clearings in the forest
in <span class="t0 t6 t7 t8 t11 t13 t14 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">order</span> to grow crops. Wood was the greatest single resource to
allow population to expand; it was the principal source of fuel and
of building materials. These early societies were intimately connected with their environment; their shamans mediated with the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> forces and the guardian spirits. The wildwood was treated with
reverence.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Part</span> of the forest was earmarked for growing sustainable wood
supplies. Mostly this was for coppicing, when the branches are cut
just above ground level <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">every</span> five to eight years. This practice produces an abundance of multipurpose straight branches and is eminently sustainable, encouraging re-growth.
The elders and the shamans selected special stands of trees for
ritual purposes, for worship and for thanksgiving. These sacred
groves were their churches and cathedrals, with altars, nave and
cloisters. Later, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> groups moved onto the savannahs, but societies <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> the Druids (dru <span class="t1 t2 t3 t6 t7 t9 t13 t14 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">means</span> wood, wid, knowledge) in Roman
times had complex tree classifications and tree medicines. The
wildwood is a magical place, and it is not surprising that there is an
immense richness of lore about the healing properties of <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span>
types of tree.
There is an area in Gloucestershire, in the <span class="t0 t1 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t16 t19 t22 t23 t25 t26 hoverable">heart</span> of England, still
<span class="t6 t10 t15 hoverable">known</span> as the Wychwood that was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> of the last stands of primitive
forest to disappear to the demands of building a wooden navy for
English control of the seas. To this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> there remains in this area an
awareness of the magical qualities of the wildwood, and a memory
of the rituals of healing and of working with the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> spirits.
The tree is at the top of the botanical ladder, and is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> a gateway
between the <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> and plant kingdoms. The forest is a community
14. THE <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">LIFE</span> AND <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span> OF TREES

with a hierarchy <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> the trees. Each area has its wise trees or
grandfather/grandmother trees. The older parent trees succour and
nourish the young saplings.
<span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Water</span> is born from the fusion of molecular hydrogen and oxygen below the surface of the Earth, through the medium of subtle
energies. The tree, with its roots deep in the ground, is intimately
connected with the evolution of water. As we have seen, <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> takes
the <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of blood, lymph, sap and milk, the life-giving and maintaining fluids which are the basis for the growth and development
of all life. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Every</span> living organism is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> a column or container
of water.

The <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of a tree
All trees have a root system that absorbs nutrients from the soil and
anchors the trunk; trunk and branches that define the shape of the
tree and raise the crown to the sunlight; and leaves that perform the
essential functions of photosynthesis, and making chlorophyll and
carbohydrates.
The roots are the complement to the branches, securing the tree
against wind and absorbing <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> that contains the energies and
the minerals the tree needs to be healthy; they <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> play a vital <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span>
in the role of the tree as a biocondenser of energy. At the ends of the
roots are magical organisms <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> protoplasms that convert the
minerals from the inorganic to the organic state that the tree is able
to use. There is a complex interaction between the roots and the
bacteria, fungi and other micro-organisms in the soil, which is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span>
of the energy exchange between the tree and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> domain.
The trunk is formed for the most <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> from dead cells that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">give</span>
it rigidity and stability. The living parts are: the cambium that produces <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> cork or bark to offset what is shed on the outside; the
phloem with fine capillaries that carry oxygen, nitrogen etc, down to
the roots, and the xylem, <span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whose</span> coarser channels allow ionized minerals, salts, trace elements, carbonic acid or CO2 to flow upwards.
Phloem and xylem are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> <span class="t0 t16 t25 t28 hoverable">found</span> in the structure of leaves, where
they perform a similar function.
The crown is the most noticeable <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the tree, comprising
branches, twigs, leaves, flowers and fruit or nuts. The leaves receive
from the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> minerals and trace elements, CO2 from the atmosphere and the Sun's energy to drive the process of photosynthesis;
HIDDEN <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span>

the by-product of which is oxygen, vital for the sustenance of the
animal kingdom and for other life-giving processes.

Trees and humans — a symbiotic relationship
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> history of a tree is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> history of water. Trees are
the <span class="t6 t9 t22 t29 hoverable">highest</span> <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of plant life, as <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> beings are of animals.
Humans and trees are marvellously interdependent (see Fig. 14.1).
Trees, through the process of photosynthesis, exhale the oxygen we
need for survival, and in return absorb the carbon dioxide we
exhale. Of their total production of oxygen, 60% is released in daylight, the balance being <span class="t27 hoverable">used</span> by the tree or plant itself during the
night to produce cool oxidations that help to build the actual
structure of the plant. As with so <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> of Nature's interdependencies, this is a symbiotic exchange, a cooperative transaction. Were
there no trees and other vegetation there <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be no animal,
<span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> or micro-organic <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> on this planet. Through our mindless
deforestation, we have already reduced the amount of oxygen and
<span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> available to us.

14. THE <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">LIFE</span> AND <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span> OF TREES
