Trees and colour

Fig. 14.2. The electromagnetic spectrum.

HIDDEN <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span>

<span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Another</span> symbiotic relationship between trees and <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> beings
is <span class="t0 t16 t25 t28 hoverable">found</span> with colour. The graph below (Fig. 14.2) shows the relative intensities of radiation in the electromagnetic spectrum, from
the ultraviolet on the left through the visual spectrum to the
infrared on the right. The darkest line shows the intensity of solar
radiation relative to frequency or to the various shades of colour.
In the visible <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the spectrum there is high <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> sensitivity
to the green and low to the red and ultraviolet, whereas with the
tree it is the opposite. A tree's sensitivity to <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> is a mirror to the
human's.
The <span class="t6 t9 t22 t29 hoverable">highest</span> intensity of solar radiation is <span class="t0 t16 t25 t28 hoverable">found</span> in the green <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span>
of the spectrum. The tree <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">cannot</span> use these frequencies for its
growth, for the greens induce dormancy. Whatever colour or frequency is not absorbed, is reflected. A red surface, for example,

absorbs all colours except its particular shade of red. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Many</span> metabolic processes are triggered by specific frequencies, and if the
required frequency of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> is not available in sufficient quantity,
then the response is blocked.
A tree will absorb most in the ultraviolet or the red to infrared
portion of the spectrum. It is insensitive to green <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> and, if placed
under green light, appears to be in a state of suspended animation.
The <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> sensitivity of the <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> eye on the other <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t29 hoverable">hand</span> is exactly
the opposite. It is insensitive to the ultraviolet and infrared frequencies, but very sensitive to the colour green.
Because we <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">cannot</span> observe any green in sunlight itself, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span>
trees and other vegetation, green <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be missing in our experience. Green is a very soothing, healing colour for humans, sedating
the nervous system and psyche. Its absence in large cities can <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">make</span>
us irritable and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> violent. Trees and humans have a symbiotic
relationship with colour.

The physical <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of trees
The structure of the tree is a record of its various stages of growth,
and this is mirrored in the movement of sap over the full span of the
tree's existence. As the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> energy of the tree recedes with ageing, the
sap sinks lower and lower, progressively drawing back from the
uppermost branches, which die off. In <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> cases this is accelerated
by <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> activity and the tree is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">said</span> to suffer from 'die-back.' <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Like</span>
an elderly <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> being, the tree's structure stiffens with age, and
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> an elderly human, its consciousness falls back through all the
stages of its previous development, perhaps re-living its earlier
experiences.
It is important in times of climate change to realize that the tree
is probably the organism least adapted to rapid change. The average
lifetime of a tree is the longest after rocks, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> centuries <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">must</span> <span class="t5 hoverable">pass</span> before any real adaptation to changed conditions
can occur. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Even</span> minor environmental changes, to which other
shorter-living <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">things</span> can adapt, can <span class="t1 t3 t9 t15 t20 t21 t26 t29 hoverable">cause</span> trees stress and vulnerability to disease, so that they wither and die.
As <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> as too <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> heat does not stress them, trees will moderate heat through their absorption of CO2 and their evapo-transpiration. When the forest cover is substantial the trees distribute
<span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> vapour evenly through the atmosphere, ensuring a balanced
14. THE <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">LIFE</span> AND <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span> OF TREES

distribution of temperature. The evaporating area of a mature
beech tree, for example, with some seven million leaves, totals
about 1.47 hectares (3.6 acres).
Trees <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> break the strength of the wind, creating shelter for
other <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> forms and lesser species of vegetation. The planting of
shelter-belts (best in spiral form) reduces both the wind speed
and the dehydration of the soil, creating microclimates that help
the soil against erosion through the provision of additional
humus and protection. Indeed shelter belts can influence the
evaporation rate over cultivated <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 hoverable">land</span> by as <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> as 30 metres
upwind and 120 metres downwind, and Canadian research has
shown that farms with a third of their <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 hoverable">land</span> as shelter belts are
more productive than farms of equivalent area where there are no
trees at all.
These shelter belts <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> trap carbon dioxide (CO2), the heaviest
naturally occurring atmospheric gas, <span class="t0 t16 t25 t28 hoverable">found</span> mostly in the lowest
levels of the atmosphere, and an essential component of photosynthesis. Increased CO2 under the <span class="t27 hoverable">right</span> conditions will produce
stronger photosynthesis. When trees and hedgerows between fields
are removed, productivity falls, because this causes a fall in carbon
dioxide. Trees should be revered as <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> as water, for <span class="t16 t21 hoverable">together</span> they
are both are the givers of life.

Tree classification
Trees can be classified generally into seven major categories. These
can be subdivided <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">according</span> to latitude, altitude, whether they are
light-demanding or shade-demanding species (the former having a
thick, rough bark and the latter a smooth thin bark), and whether
they are hardwood or softwood, broad-leafed, conifer, evergreen
and so on.
Before we examine trees and their growth in relation to these
categories in more detail, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">let</span> us look at the specific contribution that
trees <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">make</span> to the general environment. We <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">give</span> the example of a 100
year-old tree, <span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whose</span> extraordinary performance was calculated by
Walter Schauberger in the 1970s in relation to the average output of
European species:

HIDDEN <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span>

During the course of its life, a hundred-year-old tree:
a) Has processed and fixed the amount of carbon-dioxide contained in 18 million cubic metres of natural air in the <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of about 2500 kg of pure carbon (C).
b) Has photo-chemically converted 9,100 kg of CO2 and 3,700 litres of H2O.
c) Has stored up circa 23 million kilogram-calories (a calorific value equivalent to 3,500 kg of hard pit
coal).
d) Has <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> available for the respiration of <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> and beast 6,600 kg of molecular oxygen (O2).
e) Against the forces of gravity, has drawn from its roots <span class="t27 hoverable">right</span> up to its crown and evaporated into the
atmosphere at least 2,500 tonnes of water, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">every</span> tree is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> a water-column and if such a column, which continually supplies and recharges the atmosphere with water, is cut down, then this
amount of <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> is lost.
f) Thereby fixing a mechanical equivalent of heat equal to the calorific value of 2,500 kg of coal.
g) Has supplied a member of the consumer society with oxygen sufficient for 20 years, and its <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span>
is such, that the larger it grows, the more oxygen it produces.

In view of such achievements, who in the future <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> value this tree merely for its timber?
The combustion of 100 litres of petrol consumes about 230 kg of oxygen. That is, after a trip of barely
30,000 km (18,640 miles) (9 6 lit/1000 km), this tree's entire 100 year production of oxygen has been
squandered.
Driving an average size car 30,000 km (18,640 miles) = 100 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> of oxygen production.
If a <span class="t9 hoverable">person</span> chooses to breathe for <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> years, to burn 400 lit of petrol or heating oil, or 400 kg of coal,
then the production through photosynthesis of 1 tonne of oxygen is required.
1 tonne of O2 = the O2 content of 3,620 m3 of air (+15°C at latm)
The photosynthetic production of 1 tonne of oxygen necessitates:
a) The building up of 0.935 tonnes C6H12O6 (carbohydrate),
b) which process requires 1.37 tonnes CO2 (carbon-dioxide) and 0.56 tonnes H2O (water)
c) The transpiration of 230 to 930 tonnes H2O
d) <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Light</span> energy equal to 527 x 106 quanta (v = 440 x 1012) which represents 3.52 million kilocalories.

All this is no small achievement for a single organism!
[Source: Walter Schauberger]

14. THE <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">LIFE</span> AND <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span> OF TREES

Light- and shade-demanding trees
There are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> types of tree with very <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> requirements of
<span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> (see Fig. 14.3). The effect of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> on tree growth has <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span>
principal energy outcomes. Partly it determines the structure of
the timber and, secondly, it influences the <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> and character of
the tree itself, depending on whether it is a shade-demanding or
a light-demanding species; and these are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> related to latitude
and altitude.
Trees mirror the quality of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> in their natural habitat. If the
frequency of green is harmful to them, they will use green leaves as
they will screen out or repel that frequency. In general, if the incident <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> has a greater proportion of high-frequency, high-energy,
ultraviolet light, in other <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">words</span> hard light, the wood will be soft.
Conversely, where there is a greater preponderance of low-frequency, low-energy, infrared, soft light, the wood will be hard.4
Australia's native timbers, notable for their hardness, are a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span>
example of this. Because of Australias position on the Tropic of
Capricorn in the southern hemisphere, the intensity of infrared
<span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> is greatest when Australia experiences its high summer, and
when the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Earth</span> is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> at its closest to the <span class="t0 t8 t11 t14 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">Sun</span> at Perihelion in early
January. This is increased by the infrared radiation resulting from
Australia's semi-desert condition. Along with other countries in the
southern hemisphere, Australia is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> exposed to more
intense infrared <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> than counties in the north which experience
more moderate conditions.
The <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> growth of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> species of Australian trees presents a
particular mixture of red, violet and blue hues, in <span class="t0 t6 t7 t8 t11 t13 t14 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">order</span> to resist the
potentially harmful penetration of those <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> frequencies. In Europe
and the temperate latitudes of North America, on the other hand,
with their very <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> conditions, most <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> growth is <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span>
green in colour, with some exceptions (like the copper beech).
To summarize: Softwood species, such as pine, are mostly <span class="t0 t16 t25 t28 hoverable">found</span>
in zones of high-energy, high-frequency 'hard' radiation, at low altitudes in high latitudes, and at high altitudes in low latitudes. Conversely hardwood trees, with some exceptions, are generally <span class="t0 t16 t25 t28 hoverable">found</span>
at low altitudes in low latitudes (tropical rainforests) and at low to
middle altitudes at low to middle latitudes — zones of low frequency, 'soft' radiation.
HIDDEN <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span>

Tree types are determined to a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> extent by: latitude and altitude.
(1) LIGHT-DEMANDING timbers — THICK, generally rough bark (e.g. oak, black walnut)
(2) SHADE-DEMANDING timbers — THIN, generally smooth bark (e.g. beech, birch)
(3) HARDWOODS — thick (e.g. oak, jarrah) and thin bark (e.g. walnut, cherry, maple, red alder)
(4) SOFTWOODS — thick (e.g. redwood, pine, spruce) and thin bark e.g. (hemlock, fir, larch)

(5) CONIFEROUS
(evergreen)
(polar latitudes)
(high altitudes)

GENERAL
(6) DECIDUOUS
(intermittent)
(median latitudes)
(median altitudes)

DISTRIBUTION*
(7) RAINFOREST
(evergreen)
(equatorial latitudes)
(low altitudes)

*These boundaries are not necessarily clearly defined.

High altitude trees such as spruce have a relatively short lifespan. Shortwave ultraviolet light, with its higher energy and intensity, has a faster dynamic motion with a smaller radius and shorter
period tend to favour evergreens with soft wood. In contrast, low
latitude or low altitude trees <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> the beech, where <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> wavelength,
low-energy, low-frequency, less intense <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> predominates, has
harder wood and a longer lifespan.
Contemporary forestry practice requires trees to grow rapidly in
girth, putting on a profusion of branches. What this produces is a
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> quantity of poor quality timber, full of knots. The disregard by
forestry of the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> factor is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> of the causes of the deterioration
of forests.
The increase of tree diseases in both logged natural forests and
in plantations is a direct result of the exposure to direct sunlight and
heat of a shade-demanding species. There are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> ways to determine whether a tree is a light- or a shade-demander:
Shade-demanding species have thin smooth bark; growing normally
in the cooler inner forest, they do not need to insulate themselves
from the heating effect of direct sunlight. Light-demanding trees on
the other <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t29 hoverable">hand</span> have thick, coarse, thermally insulating bark, which is
Nature's <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> of protecting them from heat and direct sunlight.
14. THE <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">LIFE</span> AND <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span> OF TREES

Fig. 14.3. Tree type distribution.

Shade-demanding trees grow additional branches to protect the
trunk when exposed to <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> and heat, whereas light-demanders do
not. The shade-demanding tree is rather <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> an introvert, reserved
and extremely sensitive to external influences. They tend towards
introspection, mental activity (predominant development of the
tree's crown) and they are inwardly preoccupied and absorbed.
They need a <span class="t3 hoverable">certain</span> shielding and protection, peace and quiet to
develop to maturity and their full potential.
The light-demanding trees on the other <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t29 hoverable">hand</span> are the extroverts
that can happily stand on their own, reflecting their need for <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span>
and space around them. They tend to be more physically active,
with branches radiating outwards. They are independent, outgoing
individuals, which are generally more capable of standing on their
own feet <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> support.
Viktor Schauberger showed that the maintenance of an <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span>
inner temperature is vital to all trees, as to all organisms. When sunlight penetrates the trunk, the tree's metabolism is disrupted. It
becomes overheated, the sap no longer flows as it should and the
general structure of the tree becomes very coarse, leading to malformations, cancerous growths in the interior, and so on. All shadedemanding trees, and under <span class="t3 hoverable">certain</span> circumstances light-demanders
too, will do everything they can to maintain or reinstate their preferred inner temperature.
This can be seen after a forest fire, when the trees that survive
quickly cover themselves with a profusion of small shoots. The <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span>
has blackened their bark so that, instead of reflecting the heat, it
absorbs it and other radiation. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Without</span> protective cover the interior
of the tree <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> quickly overheat and the flow of sap <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> reduce,
no longer reaching the <span class="t6 t9 t22 t29 hoverable">highest</span> branches.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Every</span> species of tree has its particular pattern of energy frequencies, which determines its shape and supporting metabolism. If you
like, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> has <span class="t1 t2 t4 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">given</span> it a special niche in a particular environment. An
increase in temperature changes its microclimate and the plant's naturally established metabolism can no longer operate healthily, and its
wave pattern is disturbed. Instead of 'healthy tree,' there is 'sick tree +
parasites.' It is important to understand that the parasites do not <span class="t1 t3 t9 t15 t20 t21 t26 t29 hoverable">cause</span>
the sickness, but <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">come</span> as a result of it. Viktor Schauberger <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> them
'Nature's health police' because of their role in removing all organisms
that are not evolutionarily viable. The tree will rid itself of parasites
once its metabolism has returned to healthy balance.
HIDDEN <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span>

Light-induced growth
You can tell the age of a tree by counting the growth rings across the
cut trunk. These annual rings <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> tell you something about the conditions under which it grew, and about the climatic variations. Conventionally, a wider space between rings is regarded as a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> year
for the tree, because it <span class="t0 t2 t16 t18 t21 t22 t23 hoverable">put</span> on more growth; but greater quantity
does not mean better quality. What it actually signifies is a tree
under heat stress. This is best seen in Fig. 14.4; where the rings are
widely spaced on the sunny side of the trunk, the heat caused the
wood to expand; on the shaded side the metabolism has not been
disturbed and the annual rings are close together.
In a tree that grows in the shade with <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> soil conditions, the sapducts are virtually straight, producing strong vertical growth, and the
timber has what <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t18 t21 t22 t23 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">might</span> be termed a 'resonant' quality.5

Man-made depredations
Viktor measured the biomagnetic energies in a tree that are responsible not only for its physical upward growth, but <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> for transferring energies from the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Earth</span> to the atmosphere. The tree is in fact a

THE <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">LIFE</span> AND <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span> OF TREES

biocondenser, reconciling the Sun's positive, affirming energy with
the negative, receptive energy of the Earth. This important role is
seen at its most productive in the tropical rainforest, where the
enormous fecundity of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> is best observed.
Biomagnetism, a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> enhancing process that puts bioelectricity
to work, is present in all living organisms. Man-made electrical systems interfere with Nature's biomagnetism. The shortwave emissions (microwaves) of the world's communication systems have, in
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> places, seriously interfered with organic <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> on <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Earth</span> in the
last sixty years. This is seen with the appearance of <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> cancers
near radar establishments or electrical transmission lines, with
microwave ovens or portable telephones.6 It is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> damaging trees.
Radar seems to be responsible for the destruction of parts of the
German forest, and the sub-arctic forest in Canada near the line of
Defence Early Warning installations.7 Viktor observed the early evidence of radar damage to trees; however, most of the destructive
effects of microwave pollution have developed since he died.
Microwave transmitters operate with wavelengths between 2cm
and 50cm, exposure to which can inflict biological damage.
Microwaves have an energetically disruptive effect, triggering deteriorating changes in crystal structure. An example of the amount of
free ambient energy being generated can be seen from the use of a
neon-filled tube to test the system's working. Held parallel to the
direction of transmission from a microwave transmitter, or a hightension powerline, its spontaneous ignition confirms the ambient
energy's strength.8
Similar disintegrative effects are <span class="t0 t16 t25 t28 hoverable">found</span> with domestic
microwave ovens that operate on a wavelength approximately the
same as that of radar. They generate vibrational heat in the molecules of the food.9 Hydrogen, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> of the constituent atoms of the
<span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> molecule, has a wavelength of 21cm, <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t8 t10 t12 t13 t14 t17 t19 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">well</span> <span class="t5 t7 hoverable">within</span> the bandwidth of current microwave transmissions. It is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> likely to be
damaged by the excessive microwave-induced heating. In the tree
this leads to the breakdown of the structure of the sap, which <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span>
our blood, is about 80% water. This process <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> increases the
amount of available oxygen <span class="t5 t7 hoverable">within</span> the tree, which results in unnatural metabolic acceleration. The tree, being rooted to the spot,
unfortunately <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">cannot</span> escape the radiation emitted by microwave
towers and high-tension transmission grids.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Even</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> we are more mobile, humans too can <span class="t8 t13 hoverable">become</span>

increasingly prone to blood disorders if exposed excessively to such
radiation. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">People</span> living in close proximity to high-tension cables

<span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">According</span> to a study of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (CSIRO), an increase in tree ring width
of Huon pines in Australia, more rapid in the last forty <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> than in

then; there <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> have been either a <span class="t14 hoverable">series</span> of gigantic volcanic eruptions or a massive increase in cosmic radiation.

The importance of photosynthesis
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> <span class="t9 t16 t26 hoverable">works</span> through pulsation, through inhaling and exhaling,
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> the ocean tides on the shore. The rising <span class="t0 t8 t11 t14 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">Sun</span> draws up the tree's
sap charged with trace-elements, gases and minerals, to support the
process of photosynthesis and its conversion of CO2 into oxygen
(the inbreath). Photosynthesis, however, is intimately connected
with the amount and the quality of the available light. When the
level of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> falls, then growth, photosynthesis and the <span class="t14 hoverable">creation</span> of
chlorophyll diminish and less oxygen is transformed and released
into the atmosphere. Then the tide starts to ebb, and the sap ceases
to transport the nutrients upwards.
We think of photosynthesis as the process of converting CO2 to
O2 for us to breathe, but it serves <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> functions vital for the tree
itself: to convert the nutritious sap into carbohydrates (which
releases O2) and to produce evaporation in the <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of oxygen and
<span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> to cool the tree and release oxygen into the environment. This
is not the vaporization associated with sweating, but is the effect of
energy concentration or densification. Magnesium is required, in
addition to H2O and CO2, in <span class="t0 t6 t7 t8 t11 t13 t14 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">order</span> to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">make</span> chlorophyll, the green
protective pigment in the leaves, a third process which releases O2.
These <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> processes all require <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> (see Fig. 15.6).
Exactly the same chemical formula that is required to produce
chlorophyll, but <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> (i.e. underground) <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> produces
hydrogen (and magnesium carbonate). This free hydrogen is an
essential ingredient for the production of water, the other being
oxygen, which is provided by rainwater percolating into the
ground. It is exciting to <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t8 t9 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">note</span> that these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> identical combinations of Mg, H2O and CO2, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> with and the other <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> light,
14. THE <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">LIFE</span> AND <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span> OF TREES

Fig. 14.5. Photosynthesis.

are responsible for the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> creators of life, <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> and photosynthesis (see Fig. 15.6).10
We have noted a correspondence between times in the past
when forests predominated on the Earth, and with major evolutionary surges. It seems that trees have this magical role to fine-tune the
proportion of atmospheric gases, particularly oxygen. The 'normal'
proportions are O2 (oxygen) 20.95%, CO2 (carbon dioxide) 0.3%, N
(nitrogen) 78.08% and rare gases 0.93%, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> recent <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> have
seen an increase in CO2 and a decrease in O2 due to <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> activities. When we <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">say</span> that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> creates the atmosphere (effectively the
'greenhouse'), the symbiotic relationship is exceedingly complex
and miraculous.

PHOTOSYNTHESIS
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Without</span> plants there <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> be no life. Plants convert sunlight into food by a process <span class="t6 t10 t15 hoverable">known</span> as photosynthesis. They extract carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> from the soil and exhale oxygen:
1) Carbon dioxide (CO2) + <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Water</span> (H2O) = Photosynthesis + O2
in this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> carbon dioxide and hydrogen combine and molecular oxygen is released (vertical arrow)
2) CO2 + H2O + <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">LIGHT</span> -> CH2O (theoretical carbohydrate) + O2
(C6H12 O6 = glucose, the simplest <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of carbohydrate)
3) Mg + H2O + CO2 + plus <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">LIGHT</span> -> Chlorophyll + O2
(green pigment + molecular oxygen)
The same elements in (3) above produce <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> important further reactions:
(4) Mg + H2O + CO2 - minus <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">LIGHT</span> -> MgCO3 + H2
(magnesium carbonate + molecular hydrogen)
or (5) Mg + H2CO3 [carbonic acid] - minus <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">LIGHT</span> -> MgCO3 + H2
(magnesium carbonate + molecular hydrogen)
In (4) and (5) the Mg can be replaced with calcium (Ca), which produces calcium carbonate (CaCO3)
instead of magnesium carbonate, but with the same release of molecular hydrogen.
These <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> almost identical, but still <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> combinations of magnesium, CO2 and H2O are the prerequisites for the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> principal carriers of life, namely <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> and photosynthesis (creation of chlorophyll and carbohydrates). <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">One</span> of these takes <span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> in daylight (the visible world) and the other in darkness (the invisible
world). In the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> zone, O2 is released and the overall amount of oxygen increased, whereas in the night-zone,
hydrogen is released, leading to the rebirth of <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> through its combination with oxygen.

HIDDEN <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span>

The <span class="t14 hoverable">creation</span> of <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span>
There is an important relationship between rainwater and trees.
Raindrops absorb atmospheric oxygen, nitrogen and other tracegases in their descent, but their downward spinning movement <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span>
generates intense bioelectric and biomagnetic fields. This creates an
energy potential which is essentially life-endowing. When the raindrops fall on the leaves of the tree, the oxygen and other gases are
absorbed along with the immaterial energies collected, stimulating
activity and growth. For this reason plants respond with <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span>
greater vitality and activity after a fall of rain than to conventional
systems of irrigation where these gases and energies are virtually
absent, due to the <span class="t6 t9 t18 t26 hoverable">far</span> shorter fall distance.
It has frequently been observed that the planting of trees in arid
or desert conditions causes an increase in rainfall. This is probably
because chemicals that are a by-product of photosynthesis are emitted, which helps to generate clouds.11 This is <span class="t6 t10 t15 hoverable">known</span> to occur in the
tropical rainforests, and it is likely to happen in other particularly
warm areas. It is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> of the most interesting feedback mechanisms
that Gaia produces.
When the ground surface is cooler than the air (i.e. it has a positive temperature gradient) rainwater penetrates into the soil. The
free oxygen is gradually absorbed by the surrounding soil, activating micro-organisms in the humus upper layers of the soil. As the
rainwater sinks deeper into the substrata and continues to release
the excess oxygen, it gradually cools towards the +4°C anomaly
point. As we have seen, free hydrogen is now available with which
the now very passive oxygen is able to combine in the cool conditions, giving birth to <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> molecules.
This juvenile immature water, unpolluted by any other substances or ingredients, is born near the temperature when its density is highest, that is, about +4°C (39°F). It begins to rise up
through the various energy-horizons (the most finely differentiated
temperature strata), acquiring increasing 'information' in the <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span>
of subtle energies and resonances.
The <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> molecules <span class="t8 t13 hoverable">become</span> warmer as they ascend, absorbing
salts, minerals and trace-elements on the journey. Becoming ionized in the process they can be <span class="t19 hoverable">taken</span> up by the plants and their
micro-organisms. Salt (sodium chloride), for example, is broken up

The <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> has now <span class="t8 t13 hoverable">become</span> mature and can contribute <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span>
instead of seizing it, creating life-imparting macro <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> molecules
<span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whose</span> nutrients are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> more active by the increasingly available
oxygen. As these molecules are drawn up through the capillaries of
the plants or trees, their size is reduced, as energy and nutrients are
passed to structures and chemical processes at <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> levels, contributing to growth activity. Their potency increases as the molecules <span class="t8 t13 hoverable">become</span> smaller until they are able to <span class="t5 hoverable">pass</span> through the
extremely minute foramen and stomata, when their energetic quality reaches a maximum. The greatest growth and maturation occurs
at this workface, the furthest extremities of the tree, plant or blade
of grass.

The maturation of <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span>
The developmental journey from the deeper strata towards the surface transforms <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> from a seeking, 'taking' system into a ripe,
information-rich 'giving' one, when it is ready to distribute the
widest variety of ionized elements in homeopathic doses to the living systems of its environment. It is here that this alive water, rich
with minerals and trace-elements, meets the next, young, 'taking,'
information-seeking systems — the fine hair-roots of the plant systems and their micro-organisms, or 'microtransmuters.' The <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span>
is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> <span class="t19 hoverable">taken</span> up by the micro-organisms which transform the raw
materials, elements, CO2, oxygen, nitrogen, etc. into larger molecules
and fluid compounds ready for transport as larger molecules by the
capillaries of the roots.
The roots eagerly use some of these nutrients for their own
development, but the coarse macro-molecules are sucked towards
the centre and deposited in <span class="t0 t6 t7 t8 t11 t13 t14 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">order</span> to build up the central structure
of the plant or tree. This increasing, but slower flowing quantity of
formative material is built into the tree structure up to the level of
the ground-surface. Here is the threshold of the visible, energetic
world, endowed with a higher dynamic and suffused with radiant,
fertilizing energy of the Sun. This is the point where the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> aspects

of the tree, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> systems of distribution, the seen and the unseen,
meet and are united (see Fig. 15.6, p. 206).
In the <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> body, the arteries and veins narrow towards the
capillaries and enlarge towards the heart. The blood circulation is
managed by subtle differences in temperature and electric charge,
by energy density and energetic activity. There are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> principal,
pulsating circulation systems; <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> to the lungs to renew oxygen and
discharge CO2 and water; the other from the <span class="t0 t1 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t16 t19 t22 t23 t25 t26 hoverable">heart</span> to the rest of the
body, delivering nutrients and oxygen to all parts of the body, on its
return collecting and transporting CO2 and waste matter.
The tree, however, has no pulsating heart. The 'pulsators' responsible for the movement of its sap are the <span class="t0 t8 t11 t14 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">Sun</span> and the Moon. As the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> rotates, the direction of the Sun's and the Moon's attraction
fluctuates from above to below, through which a pulsation arises
between inhaling and exhaling. During the day, the sap draws the
energies up the tree ('inhaling'), while at night the energy withdraws to the root system (exhaling).
As the sap rises from the ground level, gradually the sap-ducts
and capillaries begin to narrow and the coarser elements in the sap,
unable to rise further, are built into the tree's structure at the point
where their upward movement ceases. As the sap vessels get
smaller, the faster the sap streams both upwards and downwards
and the greater the homeopathic potential. Ultimately only the most
minute particles, which are hardly to be counted as matter, stream
up towards the crown or down to the roots with increasing spiral
gyration, dynamic and energetic effect.
The growth activity is at a maximum at the extremities of crown
and root zones, because all that is active here are the most highly
potentiated homeopathic resonances and amounts of barely structured matter. This upward or downward stream of energy <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> has
a nonmaterial, form-controlling aspect. At the outside edge of the
growth process, the tree crown, energy radiates into the environment, a process of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> giving life, while at the root zone the energetic
polarity seems to be that of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> seeking life.
A <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> molecule, when it reaches the crown, carries <span class="t5 t7 hoverable">within</span> it
the highly active resonances of the trace elements previously
<span class="t19 hoverable">taken</span> up in the root zone. Refined to almost pure <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> again, with
ultra-high potency and trace element overtone resonances, it
arrives at the leaves' minute stomata. From these, it ascends into
the atmosphere towards its energy and temperature anomaly

All the processes that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">take</span> <span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> in <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> are reflected once again in

Viktor Schauberger

Sap movement
Viktor Schauberger has transformed our understanding of the
metabolism of the tree. He showed how the movement of the sap
under the conditions of both natural growth and of unnatural lightinduced growth is determined by the temperature gradient <span class="t5 t7 hoverable">within</span>
the tree itself, and by the external light, heat and cold.
The solution, transport and deposition of nutrients, as we saw in
<span class="t12 t19 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">Chapter</span> 14, are functions of the temperature gradient. Salts and
minerals are precipitated with cooling, when <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> and air are
excluded; however, they are precipitated with heating when exposed
to <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> and air. Under a positive temperature gradient, as the sap
cools towards +4°C (39°F) or is maintained at this temperature, the
<span class="t6 t9 t22 t29 hoverable">highest</span> quality nutrients are precipitated last. Under a strong negative temperature gradient and with <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> and heat, the opposite happens; only the lowest quality nutrients are expelled, the <span class="t6 t9 t22 t29 hoverable">highest</span>
quality not being transported at all.
We saw that the growth of shade-demanding trees takes <span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span>
largely in the crown where the air temperature is usually higher
than at ground level. The tree's overall shape is cylindrical, with few
lower branches, because there is no need to protect the trunk
against light. Lacking horizontal lighting, the trunk does not suffer
large temperature fluctuations, so it produces closely <span class="t1 t2 t4 t7 t15 t17 t18 t19 hoverable">set</span> annual
rings. The temperature in the trunk reduces from the outside
inwards, resulting in an <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> deposition of growth material, which
<span class="t1 t2 t3 t6 t7 t9 t13 t14 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">means</span> high quality and dense timber. These shade-demanders have
a slender girth because of their strong vertical sap movement, high
health and associated levitational energies, that in a mature tree
enables it to withstand gales.
When a shade-demander is planted out in the open it has to cope
with unnatural levels of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> and heat, protecting itself as quickly
as possible by sending out branches <span class="t27 hoverable">right</span> down to the ground, at the

expense of its upward growth. It develops a cone-shaped form, with

In its early years, due to high <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> exposure, a plantation tree
exhibits wide annual rings and abnormal lateral branch growth (see
Fig. 15.1). Once it receives some protection from its neighbours, the
need for lateral branch growth diminishes and it will tend to grow
upwards. However, in commercial woodland, the trees are thinned
after a prescribed period, those considered suitable for use in construction going to the sawmill and the remainder to the pulp-mill.
This thinning out exposes the remaining trees to excess heat and
light. All their growth energy is diverted to growing branches on the
exposed <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the trunk, mainly on the sunny side, which produces knots and twisted, spongy grain.
The annual tree rings tell the story of a tree's exposure to light.
In Fig. 15.1, the rings near the middle show that in its early years,
this 33-year <span class="t25 hoverable">old</span> tree was exposed to unnatural levels of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> and
heat. The healthiest growth was in middle third of the tree's life,
revealed by the annual rings at their closest. Its last <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> show the
stress it experienced when its protecting neighbours were removed.
High quality, resonant timber <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> be cut only from the area of
closely spaced rings. A board cut from the full width of the trunk
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> warp as a result of the unevenness of the grain. For practical
purposes the only source of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> narrow-ringed timber that is firm
and regular in its structure and less likely to warp, is a mature tree
from a natural forest. A shade-demander in a natural forest or a
plantation that is suddenly exposed to <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> will show irregular
annual rings, an off-centre heart, sometimes heartrot, and radial
cracks (called 'shakes') <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> those shown in Fig. 15.1. Excessive heating, causing sponginess in the wood that often results in <span class="t0 t1 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t16 t19 t22 t23 t25 t26 hoverable">heart</span> rot,
and encourages bacteria and parasites causes the openness of the
grain. This combination of conditions Viktor Schauberger <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span>
'tree cancer.'
The conventional theory is that the movement of sap is caused
by osmosis, or by differences in pressure between air pressure and
the pressure in the capillaries. However, the absorbent raising action
of osmosis is limited, and <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">cannot</span> account for the rising of sap in the
<span class="t6 t9 t22 t29 hoverable">highest</span> trees, which can exceed 91m (300ft). Mechanical suction
<span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">cannot</span> be responsible either, as the limit for drawing up <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> is

in trees <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">cannot</span> be explained by the physical factors hitherto

of the tree and is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> a result of the vital activity of the
capillary tree-cell. Professor Kurt Bergel of Berlin <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">came</span> to
similar conclusions in relation to the activity of the <span class="t0 t1 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t16 t19 t22 t23 t25 t26 hoverable">heart</span> and
the blood in animal life.1
The healthy movement of sap is stimulated both by the pulsating
action and by the extreme fineness of the capillaries to be <span class="t0 t16 t25 t28 hoverable">found</span> in
a completely naturally grown tree (Fig. 15.2). When the carbonic
acid contained in the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> and sap is warmed, it is converted into

Fig. 15.2. Rising sap.
As the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> warms bubbles of CO2 completely fill
the narrow capillaries <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> corks, pushing water,

the sap sinks, sucking down the CO2, the sap
and the nutrients.

Fig. 15.3. Viktor designed this surprisingly simple but ingenious experiment that anyone can replicate with simple laboratory equipment,
which consists of a U-tube, the bend of which is filled with pure quartz sand that is then saturated with salt water. This effectively separates
and prevents communication between each side of the U-tube, but the salt <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> can be displaced laterally when pressure is higher in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> arm.
The top of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> arm has attached an adaptor to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> fine capillary tubes, which allow contact with the air. The other arm has four fine
capillaries attached to it. Both arms are now filled with fresh high quality spring <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> with little oxygen content, which has not been
exposed to the Sun, or for <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> to the air.
The U-tube is then placed in an insulated container, e.g. a bucket, containing ice at the bottom, and then filled with <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> loam. The
ice will create an artificial environment of +4°C (39°F) at the bend of the U-tube, helping to <span class="t22 hoverable">bring</span> about a positive temperature gradient
from the top of the loam downwards.
The container is then placed in the heat of the <span class="t0 t8 t11 t14 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">Sun</span> and slowly as the +4°C (39°F) temperature is reached below and the higher <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span>
heats up, the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> level in the arm with 4 outlets will rise and overflow as there is less resistance on that side, the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> on the other side
remaining level. The rise in the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> level is assisted by the heat of the <span class="t0 t8 t11 t14 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">Sun</span> converting the carbonic acid in the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> into carbon dioxide
bubbles that push the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> bundles ahead of the them and pull the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> behind, creating a pulsating effect.
During the night the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> on the 4-capillary side subsides, the carbones in the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> having absorbed the oxygen and other gases from
the atmosphere. This makes it specifically heavier, exerting pressure through the sand barrier on the other side of the U-tube, causing the
<span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> level in this tube to rise up its pair of capillaries.
This replicates the natural process of pulsation that happens with all liquids in Nature, a pulsation which is caused by temperature difference,
pressure and suction. This experiment sets out to duplicate particularly the conditions under which sap rises in the daytime (the four capillaries
representing the xylem tubelets), falling back at night <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> (the pair of capillaries approximate the delivery of the phloem tubelets).
To demonstrate the action of a natural spring, the adaptor with four capillaries is removed, leaving the shorter side open, so that the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span>
rises and overflows on that side when the temperature difference is greatest between the +4°C (39°F) environment at the bottom of the
bucket, and that at the surface of the loam. At night the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> drops on the open side, rising on the side with the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> capillaries.

HIDDEN <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span>

carbon dioxide, which forms bubbles. These bubbles act <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> little
plugs and, as they rise, push the intervening packets of water, sap,
etc, ahead of them, pumping the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> with the nutrients and the
sap <span class="t27 hoverable">right</span> up to the furthest extremities of the crown.
The sap rises during the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> when the tree exhales oxygen
through photosynthesis. When the <span class="t0 t8 t11 t14 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">Sun</span> sets and the temperature
drops, this process is reversed as it breathes in oxygen to help build
up the root system and the trunk of the tree. Nightfall initiates the
retreat of the sap, which becomes denser through cooling and is
drawn towards the root-zone. The capillaries in the crown of the
tree are evacuated, creating a partial biological vacuum as the CO2
gas-bubbles condense and begin to sink (see Fig. 15.6).
The CO2, nitrogen, oxygen, starches, sugars, and trace gases
formed during daytime photosynthesis are drawn down through the
minute stomata and pores in the leaves, down the trunk, some of
them reaching the hair-roots. Their purpose here is to nourish the
life-functions of the tree during the night and provide the material
for building the structure of the inner fabric of the tree as a whole.
As the crown and the trunk cool down, the root-zone warms up and
the opposite happens to what <span class="t4 hoverable">took</span> <span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> during the day. This keeps
the soil warm during the night and in winter, and cooler during the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> and in summer. The ground temperature in this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> is prevented
from overcooling or overheating, greatly benefiting the micro-organisms in the humus.
Light-demanding trees are able to <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> in the same <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> because
they have thick bark or, in some cases, a light-coloured bark with a
high reflective factor to protect them from the greater heat and <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span>
which <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> interfere with this delicately balance metabolic
process.
The cambium layer (see Fig. 15.4, p. 204) is the active zone where
the growth of the tree takes <span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> through the interaction of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span>
electrically charged fluids. The negatively charged phloem containing oxygen, carbon dioxide, nitrogen, etc, flows down the inner side
of the dielectric, while the positively charged xylem, containing ionized minerals, salts, trace-elements, carbonic acid or CO2, flows up
the outside. Between these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> streams and through their interaction, the proto-annual ring is transformed into a proper annual
ring. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> history of the tree is imprinted on these annual rings.

This shows how the growth rings act as charge
