Temperature gradients in the tree
Temperature gradients are important in tree metabolism. The areas
of active growth in the outer trunk and in the branches need heat
energy to sustain the formative elements in a productive, ionized
and fluid state for the processes of combination and re-combination
to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">take</span> place.
During the daytime, a positive temperature gradient is active
from the outside inwards, the cooler, more internal sap rising faster,
transporting the finest nutrients up to the top of the tree. They are
<span class="t19 hoverable">taken</span> to the foliage, for the small green shoots, flowers and reproductive elements required for the <span class="t6 t9 t22 t29 hoverable">highest</span> quality growth. Viktor
Schauberger's measurements showed that this upward flow <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span>
be as fast as 3m (10ft) per hour, or 50mm (2ins.) per minute. The
lower quality, coarser nutrients present in the outermost layers of
the cambium ring (just inside the bark), needed for building the
structure of the tree, are raised only as <span class="t6 t9 t18 t26 hoverable">far</span> as their fineness permits,
the coarser being deposited in the trunk, the finer later in the
branches. The effectiveness of this process depends on a negative
temperature gradient being active from the outside inwards (cooler
HIDDEN <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span>

outside > warmer inside) during the hours of darkness, in its function as depositor or precipitator.
With rising air temperatures, the point where the positive and
negative temperature gradients meet <span class="t5 t7 hoverable">within</span> the tree shifts to deeper
levels. The flow of the sap becomes more sluggish and the positively
charged nutritive elements are held in near stationary suspension at
various heights to await the arrival of the negatively charged elements from above. This <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> be the reason why the Amazonian rainforest stops producing oxygen towards midday. The positive
nutrient-transporting temperature gradient soon changes to a negative <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> as the temperatures rise rapidly during the morning. This
arrests the supply of nutrients; photosynthesis ceases and with it,
the expiration of oxygen is interrupted.
With nightfall and the cooling air, the temperature gradient
reverses to positive from the inside outwards, so that the outer layers of the tree <span class="t8 t13 hoverable">become</span> cooler than the inner. The crown cools faster,
causing the sap to sink quickly. The higher temperatures of the
Amazon rainforest <span class="t1 t3 t9 t15 t20 t21 t26 t29 hoverable">cause</span> fast evaporation, to <span class="t22 hoverable">bring</span> accelerated

in daytime, descending at night.

The vital exchange between the yang solar and the yin <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> energies for the production of photosynthesis,
chlorophyll and carbohydrates and its role in the production of water.

cooling of the sap which, sinking after midday, does not reverse
direction until the following day. The oxygen and other gases contained in the negatively-charged phloem are drawn down towards
the root-zone. By this means, oxygen is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> available to assist
decay in the upper reaches of the soil, and to stimulate growth
around the root tips (Fig. 15.6).
During the night the descending phloem plays <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">another</span> important role. It interacts with suspended positively-charged xylem and
because of the prevailing positive temperature gradient (Figs. 15.4
and 15.5) is drawn towards the exterior of the trunk. This produces
<span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> wood growth that is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> denser and harder with winter cold,
forming an annual ring.
In a commercial plantation a shade-demanding tree grows more
branches in <span class="t0 t6 t7 t8 t11 t13 t14 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">order</span> to protect itself. The sap is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> diverted from
its normal progress up the trunk to nourish the spurious branches,
twisting around the extra knots in the trunk. The excess heat <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span>
makes the sap ducts larger in diameter so that the carbon-dioxide
bubbles are not able raise the fluids required for healthy growth.
Insufficient nutrients are able to reach the crown of the tree, which
is likely to suffer die-back; high quality timber is no longer produced, and the tree will have a limited lifespan. Sprouting foliage
shows the height to which the sap is able to rise.
Because of unnatural high internal temperatures there is premature deposition of nutrients, a condition akin to arterio-sclerosis in the blood vessels of humans. The higher temperature <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span>
limits the rise of these coarse materials, which are deposited near
the base of the trunk, causing a cone-shaped trunk. With its levitational energies <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> weakened, such a tree more easily falls victim
to storms.

The tree as a biocondenser
We discussed earlier how the formative energies (which belong to
the fourth and fifth dimensions) carry the blueprint for the evolution and physical manifestation of all organisms. This life-force carries with it an electrical charge. The process of growth and
development of any organism requires that this life-force is
enhanced or potentiated by a process <span class="t6 t10 t15 hoverable">known</span> as biocondensing.
As <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of its important role in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> associated with the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> creators of life, <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> and photosynthesis, the tree acts as a biocondenser,
15. THE METABOLISM OF THE TREE

Fig. 15.7. Various root systems.
In the evolution of plants, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> primitive ones (a
& b) <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">take</span> root, making use of the low-grade
nutrients at the warm surface. They allow a little
soil and moisture to accumulate. As the soil cools
off, the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> table slowly rises, bringing up
deeper minerals and nutrients. This allows higher
plant forms to develop (c to i), which hold the soil
<span class="t16 t21 hoverable">together</span> and encourage humus to form, which
attracts micro-organisms that break down the soil,
increasing the fertility and richness, causing the
pioneer plants to die off.

<span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whose</span> purpose is to increase the potency of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> force towards the
tips of both branches and roots.
In <span class="t12 t19 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">Chapter</span> 7, we saw how the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Earth</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> <span class="t8 t13 hoverable">become</span> charged with <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span>
energy through its terrestrial biocondenser. Trees <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> in a similar
manner, the annual rings forming the dielectric separators between the
electrically charged areas. When these are closer together, the potential
(the dynamic energy) is increased, which occurs higher up the trunk.
In the central <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the trunk some growth takes place, but the most
energetic growth happens at the ends of the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> shoots.
The diameter of the trunk reduces as the tree grows taller, which
makes the annuals rings grow closer together, increasing the bioelectric potential. At the very top of the tree the potential is very high.
Finally in the leaves themselves the energy potential is at its maximum.
This is necessary for the critical process of evapo-transpiration to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">take</span>
place. The sap capillaries are extremely small, so that the substances
HIDDEN <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span>

having only the finest materials with the <span class="t6 t9 t22 t29 hoverable">highest</span> of nutritive qualities
remain, the coarser having been left behind to build up the structure of
the lower <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the tree.
In addition, this refinement of the energy at the leaves gives it a
kind of increased homeopathic potency; so that when they receive
the highly energized drops of falling rainwater there is an immediate transfer of pure energy or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> force. It is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> hardly surprising that this is where the most intense growth takes place.
These areas of dense growth where the biocondensers are
located are finely structured and susceptible to damage, either by
being pierced, or disturbed by excessive warming. If this happens,
the biocondenser fails, disease sets in and the tree dies.
By inserting copper probes, Walter Schauberger was able to
record significantly high electrical charges between the cambium
layer and the <span class="t0 t1 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t16 t19 t22 t23 t25 t26 hoverable">heart</span> of the trunk, sufficient to <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> a small flashlight
bulb. The healthier and more naturally had the tree grown, the
brighter the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> observed.

Root systems
The root system, being the invisible <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the tree, has an aura of
mystery. A germinating seed puts down a root into the darkness before
it sends a shoot into the light. The root system is the complement to
the canopy, and its energy exchange system is just as complex.
It is important to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">see</span> the <span class="t3 t5 t7 t9 t20 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> tree as an energy pathway that
brings about a marriage of the negatively charged energies of the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Earth</span> (a receptive, female system) with the positively charged energies of the atmosphere and the <span class="t0 t8 t11 t14 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">Sun</span> (a radiating, male system). Out
of this union comes the primary manifestation of the organism,
'tree' — with its secondary life-enhancing processes of chlorophyll
production and photosynthesis.
We are taught wrongly that there is a one-way transport of
nutrients from the roots to the leaves. The very fine root tips, with
their tiny capillaries, correspond to the new, growing leaves in the
tree canopy, and at night the descending energies and nutritive elements contribute to the important processes that these root tips
perform.
At the ends of the root tips are tiny protoplasms, little chemical
factories that perform the important task of converting minerals
from their natural metallic to the organic <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> that the tree is able
15. THE METABOLISM OF THE TREE

to absorb. They are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> responsible for transferring yang energy
and nutritive elements derived from the tree crown, to increase the
vitality of the soil, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> which the micro-organisms <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be
unable to flourish. In addition, they release hydrogen, which combines with free oxygen in the soil to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">give</span> birth to <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> water. So it is
clear that these protoplasms perform invaluable functions.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Even</span> a gardener probably has only the vaguest idea of how a root
system develops. To hold up the plant stem is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> purely physical
function. There is, in fact, the widest possible variety of root forms
and systems, the diversity of which is essential to healthy microenvironment, because each species' roots go down to a <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span>
level in the soil, bringing up <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> nutrients and energies.
Trees are described as being flat-rooted, heart-rooted, taprooted and deep-rooted, the last evaporating more <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> than
heart-rooted trees, and flat-rooted trees evaporating least of all.
Each plant species, therefore, has its own particular root structure,
which penetrates to a <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> soil horizon to withdraw the elements it needs. But other plants will share some of these nutrients
also. Fig. 15.7 illustrates the wide variety of root systems.
When plants <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> appeared, about 420 million <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> ago, climatic
conditions were inhospitable, with severe storms and heavy rain.
Only the most primitive plants <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> gain a hold, feeding on the salts
and metallic minerals. Although they had very little root growth, the
stems above ground were able to trap some nutritive wind-borne
dust to <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> very primitive soil, their shadows having a slight cooling effect on the ground, allowing some moisture to collect.

Soil and nutrition
Cooling was the key to the appearance of water, and as the ground
cover spread, the lowering temperature affected the deeper ground,
allowing the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> table to rise, bringing with it minerals, trace elements and nutritional substances nearer to the surface. This created
the conditions for higher quality plants to evolve. Requiring better
quality nutrition, these higher plants had deeper root systems that
<span class="t2 t4 t5 t22 t23 hoverable">brought</span> up minerals from a <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> horizon, but were no competition for the pioneer plants.
The more evolved plants held the soil together, trapping more
moisture that helped to attract micro-bacterial activity to break
down the mineral particles into finer dust, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> step towards the
HIDDEN <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span>

humus that is necessary for <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> higher plant forms. The root systems <span class="t8 t13 hoverable">become</span> more complex, interweaving at <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> levels, so that
they <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">cannot</span> easily be separated. Greater fertility brings a richer soil
that is of too high a quality for the pioneer plants, which will now
disappear. A more favorable microclimate in the higher soil
increases the diversity of the bacteria, encouraging more complex
root systems.
There is a magical and symbiotic relationship between the various root systems that we <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">cannot</span> easily observe below ground, more
complex than the interrelationships of the plants above ground.
With greater complexity, and the evolution of trees, the soil takes on
the full yin energy potential of Mother Earth, and with it the <span class="t14 hoverable">creation</span> of virgin water, an essential requirement for higher <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> forms.
This process of soil formation <span class="t4 hoverable">took</span> several million <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> before
larger plants, such as small bushes and trees, were able to gain a
hold; and they had to go through thousands of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> of evolution
before a forest was possible. The forest is the most productive environment for the building up of soil and fertile humus. It is self-fertilizing and self-sustaining. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> forests were able, over a
period of thousands of years, to build up twenty feet or more of soil
depth. With our heedless disrespect for Nature's bounty, in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> century we have allowed these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> soil banks to be eroded and
destroyed, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> through deforestation, and then by careless tilling of
the unprotected soil surface.
The web of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> that evolves in a natural forest is so complex and
sensitive that the removal of key species can <span class="t1 t3 t9 t15 t20 t21 t26 t29 hoverable">cause</span> a depletion of the
energy that can lead to a progressive decline of the system, as more
species fail for want of the sustenance that was provided by the
missing species. A hole is created in the complex root network that
is the interconnecting link between the deeper ground and the surface. The root system raises the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> table. A missing species <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span>
<span class="t1 t2 t3 t6 t7 t9 t13 t14 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">means</span> a hole is created in the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> system that supplies the nutrients. Over time, a shortage of nutrients puts more plants under
stress, leading to more species disappearing.
Something <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> this happens with our monoculture systems, for
the nutrients are not able to rise through the crusty layer formed at
the level to which all the same species' roots descend. This leads to
depletion of fertility and all the energies associated with it; uniformity <span class="t1 t2 t3 t6 t7 t9 t13 t14 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">means</span> sterility, something that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> abhors.

Working with <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span>

Our primeval Mother <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Earth</span> is an organism that no science in the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> can rationalize. Everything on her that crawls and flies is
dependent <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> her and all <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">must</span> hopelessly perish if that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Earth</span> dies
that feeds us.
Viktor Schauberger1

The crisis in intensive farming
When there was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> enthusiasm in the 1930s for the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> publicized glamour of industrialized agriculture, Viktor Schauberger was
very aware of its pitfalls, developing a number of field tests which
demonstrated the fallacy of the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> technologies. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Though</span> he did
not live to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">see</span> the dramatic agricultural catastrophes of the 1990s,
to a large extent he predicted them.
Intensive farming developed <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> in the Americas, where the
limitless vast open plains <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> be cultivated or grazed in only very
large units. At <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> in North America, and then on the South American plains, this meant enormous herds of cattle or highly mechanized crop cultivation. Because of the inevitable depletion of
minerals and, as a consequence of monoculture, intensive farming
of this kind soon leads to the widespread use of chemical drugs or
artificial fertilization with animals, and herbicides with cultivation.
By its very <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> intensive agriculture is unsustainable, but it is a
big and profitable international industry and, as we all know, we are
living at a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> where big profits count for more than <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> or ecological values.
There is a growing interest in sustainable cultivation, and
there are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> books on the topic. It is impossible to grow crops
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> a loss of fertility in the soil. We <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">shall</span> be examining <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> methods of fertilization from the inorganic to increasingly
higher organic and energetic processes. Viktor Schauberger's
<span class="t3 t5 t7 t9 t20 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> research was deeply committed to improving food quality
and soil fertility. He had original ideas about fertilization, but his
most intriguing ideas were concerned with amplifying the subtle
energies of the planet to <span class="t22 hoverable">bring</span> about higher quality in the plants
themselves.
16. SOIL FERTILITY AND CULTIVATION

Ploughing methods
Viktor Schauberger's interest in soils was initiated during a visit to
Bulgaria in the 1930s where he had been commissioned to build a
log-flume. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Boris asked him to look into the decline in soil productivity and the shrinkage of the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> table in the northern parts
of the country since the introduction of modern mechanized farming methods. The southern part, on the other hand, was still fertile,
with abundant moisture.
Viktor <span class="t0 t16 t25 t28 hoverable">found</span> that in the poorer southern <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the country,
populated largely by <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> of Turkish origin, the fields were
tilled with traditional wooden ploughs pulled usually by teams of
women. These fields remained very fertile and productive, with
high crop quality. In the north, however, the fields were ploughed
with tractor-drawn steel ploughs. As he was aware of the destructive effect that steel and iron have on <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> in the soil,
Schauberger attributed the disappearance of the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> and the
poorer yields to the use of the steel ploughs and the faster
ploughing in the north. This <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> led him to invent a <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span>
kind of plough and to do a number of experiments on improving
soil fertility. Before going into this, however, we need to understand more about electromagnetism.

<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Two</span> kinds of electromagnetism
Viktor already recognized that in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> there are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> types of electromagnetism, just as there are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> kinds of temperature change.
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> that encourages growth and stimulates energies in all
organisms he <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> biomagnetism or bioelectricity; the elements
connected with this <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of electromagnetism (diamagnetism) are
copper, bismuth and gold.
The other, ferromagnetism, usually just <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> magnetism,
when combined with an electric current, is the <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> that is commonly <span class="t27 hoverable">used</span> in electric motors and dynamos for the generation of
electricity. In <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> this <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of energy is <span class="t27 hoverable">used</span> to break down
substances. In water's case it disintegrates the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> particles into
its constituent atoms. The elements of ferromagnetism are iron,
nickel and cobalt.

HIDDEN <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span>

The golden plough
Wherever we look, the dreadful disintegration of the bridges of life,
the capillaries and the bodies they have created, is evident, which has
been caused by the mechanical and mindless <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of Man, who has
torn <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">away</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> from the Earth's blood — water.
Viktor Schauberger2
Viktor observed how steel ploughs damage the soil. Drawn rapidly through the ground, the hard steel ploughshares generate
minute ferro-electric and ferro-magnetic currents that decompose the nutrient-laden <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> molecules in the soil, in a manner
similar to electrolysis, resulting in <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> loss. The surface tension
of the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> molecule is reduced, the soil loses its energy potential and its nutritive subtle energies are dissipated. This not only
destroys the soil's subtler energies, but <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> converts the nutritive
elements or removes them from the mature <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> molecule. The
residual <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> becomes pure juvenile <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> that has no nutritive
value.
Abrasion with the soil removes tiny particles of steel from the
cutting surface of the plough, which break down to rust, an ideal
breeding ground for harmful pathogenic bacteria. An increase in
the iron content of soil inhibits its <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> retention. On the other
hand, soils high in copper have the capacity to retain greater quantities of water.
The delicate soil capillaries that deliver nutrients and <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> to
the surface, and some of the micro-organisms that process them are
destroyed by the heat-producing friction and the compacting pressure of the steel plough. As the normal supply of nutrients from
below is cut off and the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> table falls, the soil fertility suffers.
Schauberger started to experiment with copper, initially as a
plating of thick copper over a conventional steel plough. The
destructive ferro-electromagnetic effects of the steel plough were
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> replaced by beneficial bioelectromagnetic ionization, enhancing growth and soil fertility. Because of the remarkable results it
achieved, this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">came</span> to be <span class="t6 t10 t15 hoverable">known</span> as the 'Golden Plough.'
Field trials were conducted near Salzburg in 1948 and 1949 to
compare the results of the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> plough with the conventional steel
plough. Fields strips were ploughed, alternately using steel and

copper-plated ploughs. When the grain <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">came</span> up the differences
between the alternate strips was quite apparent. Where the copperplated plough had been <span class="t27 hoverable">used</span> the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> content and the nutrient

6-8 inches higher with a <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> fuller head. Some yields in the
strips ploughed with copper-plated implements increased by up to
40% compared to the control strips where conventional steel
ploughs were used. As all other factors of soil chemistry, orientation, furrow width, etc., were identical, the difference in yield was
clearly due to the use of the copper plated plough.
With <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> crops there were spectacular results. 15cm <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> ears of

experiment in Tyrolean Kitzbuhel potatoes weighing nearly half a
kilo, containing over twenty eyes' (the source of next year's crop),
were produced (Fig. 16.2).

The Bio-plough
The conventional ploughshare forms a pressure wave and makes a
crushing cut that destroys the soil capillaries. Schauberger in 1948
encouraged a Hamburg engineer Jurgen Sauck to develop a sharp
curved blade to create a <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> slicing cut before the soil is centripetally involuted in a figure of eight motion through the curving
wings of the phosphor-bronze ploughshare, copying the burrowing

HIDDEN <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span>

Fig. 16.3. The bio-plough, 1948.

action of the mole. This was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> the bio-plough (Fig. 16.3)
because it enhanced the energy in the soil. Its action was to rotate
the soil through 360°, so that what was originally on the surface was
returned to the surface. This minimized <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> loss and the sub-surface micro-organisms were <span class="t0 t10 t11 t14 t18 hoverable">never</span> exposed to direct sunlight (heat)
and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> continue their <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> undisturbed.
These experiments clearly proved the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> advantage of the copper-based ploughs. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> increase in productivity with their use
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> quickly recover the cost of replacing iron or steel ploughs. The
trials had created a lot of interest, but Viktor <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">came</span> up against bureaucratic corruption that defeated his plans. Copper being in short supply just after the war, he had to go to the Ministry of Agriculture to
obtain what he needed. It is alleged that the Minister was being
seduced with large bribes by the chemical companies to introduce
chemical fertilizers, and indicated that he expected Viktor to do the

same. Of course Viktor <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> not, so the copper ploughs <span class="t0 t10 t11 t14 t18 hoverable">never</span> <span class="t0 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">went</span>

countries, the copper ploughs were forgotten about, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> the
Schauberger research institute, the PKS, has encouraged the development of copper gardening tools that are now being marketed in
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> countries (see Resources).

Alignment of furrows
In his study of crop yields in Bulgaria, Viktor Schauberger realized
that there were factors other than the use of steel versus wooden
ploughs to explain the differences in productivity between the
north and south. The fields in the north were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> harrowed, which
broke the soil into <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> smaller particles and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> it more vulnerable to drying out in the hot <span class="t0 t8 t11 t14 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">sun</span> to several inches of depth.
In the Turkish south of the country, the farmers <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> not afford
to harrow, and their ploughing was <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> more rough and ready.
The furrows they <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> were irregular and rough, producing large
clods that fell in <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> directions. The unevenness of the furrows
meant that there were no large flat surfaces to absorb the heat of the
Sun. This messy looking surface <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> had the advantage of holding
the moisture in the top layers of the soil.
The lesson to be learned from these examples was to cut sinuous furrows so as to vary exposure to the Sun's rays, but in addition
to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">give</span> them a north-south alignment, so that the inclined surfaces
of the furrows <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be shaded for <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> and exposed to
the <span class="t0 t8 t11 t14 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">Sun</span> only when it was low in the sky. This meant that the young
growing sprouts had the maximum amount of moisture when most
needed.

Grazing and grass cutting
Conventional mechanical grass mowers have an effect on the grass
similar to that of the standard iron plough on the soil. The inclined
blade uses a crushing action that damages the capillaries of the
grass stalks, and shreds the top of the stalks for several millimetres,
allowing the grass to bleed and bacteria to enter. Instead of applying its energies to <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> growth, the grass stems have to heal the
wounds, which can <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">take</span> a week.
Viktor Schauberger's observation of animals was profound. He
HIDDEN <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">NATURE</span>

would watch the cows on the fertile high Alpine pastures. The grazing animal gathers the grass stems <span class="t16 t21 hoverable">together</span> in a spiralling movement with its tongue, cutting them with a jerk of its head so as not
to damage the stalks. It then seals the ends of the stalks with its
moist nose to prevent the loss of moisture and energy.
The Alpine farmers needing as <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> winter fodder as they
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> get, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> crop the grass sometimes <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> times in the summer. Their implement is the much-cherished scythe that delivers a
long, slicing cut, thereby keeping the wound area to a minimum. But
more than that, their method of sharpening the blade imparts to it
an ionizing energy that draws <span class="t16 t21 hoverable">together</span> the damaged fibres and rapidly seals the wound.
Those who have lived close to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 hoverable">land</span> for <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> generations use
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> as their teacher. These farmers knew that sharpening a
scythe with a stone robs it of its charge of energy. Instead they
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> hammer the blade on a block of hardwood which enhanced
the electrical charge. Mounted on a wooden handle, wrapped in
cloth and stored in darkness ensured that it <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> keep its charge.
Schauberger understood that the Sun's <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> and heat <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> discharge a newly sharpened scythe and, for that reason, these farmers <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> do their blade hammering early or late, and their scything
in the early morning or evening. The accumulated energies <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> be
seen as minute glowing sparks on the blade, leaping from <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> serration to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">another</span> in the growing darkness of a summer evening.
We have lost this knowledge, and today soil fertility and productivity are in dangerous decline, ironically, because of the heavy use
of artificial fertilizers as <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t8 t10 t12 t13 t14 t17 t19 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">well</span> as misguided techniques.

Artificial fertilizers
Contemporary agriculture treats Mother-Earth <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> a whore and
rapes her. All year round it scrapes <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">away</span> her skin and poisons it with
artificial fertilizer, for which we have to thank a science that has lost
all connection with Nature.
Viktor Schauberger3
The pioneer of modern artificial fertilizers was Justus von Liebig
(1803-1873), a German chemist. His research into the elements and
chemicals required by plants for growth <span class="t0 t16 t25 t28 hoverable">found</span> that four principal
minerals were often deficient in agricultural soils. To increase fertility he advocated the supplementation of calcium (Ca) in the <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of
16. SOIL FERTILITY AND CULTIVATION

lime, nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P) and potassium (K), the last
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> often referred to as NPK.
These products are soluble and mostly they are by-products of
what Viktor Schauberger <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> 'fire-spitting technology' They are
produced by heat, which is structure-disintegrating and energydepleting and applied by either spraying or by powder diffusion.
Chemical companies were quick to manufacture these <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span>
products as a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> of turning waste material to profit. Liebig later
realized that the ingredients necessary for healthy plant growth
were <span class="t6 t9 t18 t26 hoverable">far</span> more complex than simple NPK. Indeed he warned that
dependence on these basic chemicals <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> irreparably damage the
soil, but nobody was listening. The rapid spread in the use of artificial fertilizers led to a systematic depletion of soil fertility as it lost
its organic base. A highly mechanized system of cultivation, using
steel ploughs and artificial fertilizers reduced large tracts of midwestern America to dustbowls, forcing the ruined farmers to leave
their land. The same is now happening in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> third <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> countries, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> India, where multinational chemical companies are
demanding the replacement of traditional methods in favour of
chemically dependent agriculture.
When the dependence on chemicals was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> exported, it was
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> 'the green revolution,' because their use was linked to
increased yields. However, this was quantity at the cost of continually decreasing quality, profit at the expense of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> (see <span class="t12 t19 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">Chapter</span> 5).
Artificial fertilizers are stimulants to growth and act <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> narcotics
on which the soil becomes reliant. The soil, now dependent on the
chemicals — rather <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> drug addicts who as their physical condition worsens, require more and more shots to extend their lives a little further — is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> dying.
In their finely powdered form, artificial fertilizers are moisture
demanding, robbing the lower ground strata and the young plants
of moisture. With insufficient moisture, transpiration is reduced
and the plants' internal temperatures rise, making them more susceptible to disease. These fine powders block the vital capillaries,
which supply naturally derived nutrients, mature water, and conduct rising immaterial energies. This makes it more difficult for the
plants to absorb rain, resulting in rapid runoff and faster re-evaporation. Irrigation, with virtually worthless water, now becomes a
necessity. It is not surprising that the crops grown in such conditions are <span class="t4 t18 t22 hoverable">neither</span> particularly tasty nor nourishing.

Excess nitrogen can <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> introduce <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">another</span> problem — which
makes ionized substances less available for root development, leading to further <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> shortage for the plants. Nitrates have negatively
charged ions (anions -) that capture the positively charged ions
(cations +) of elements such as magnesium and calcium, removing
them from the root zone. Magnesium is essential for chlorophyll
production.
Natures remedy is to <span class="t22 hoverable">bring</span> in parasites (the 'Health Police') to
remove the diseased organisms, requiring the application of pesticides and fungicides. After passing on a pesticide-treated crop to
the consumer, the ground is fumigated with poisonous gases
injected through plastic sheets, to eradicate these supposedly pernicious pests. Everything dies — earthworms, micro-organisms
and beneficial bacteria alike. A diverse biosystem gives <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> to a lifeless desert. The green revolution was justified as a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> of feeding
the world, just as is biotechnology today. The holistic biologist MaeWan Ho gives <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> examples of how sustainable organic agriculture can be more productive than chemical farming, which is both
unsustainable and destructive of life.4

16. SOIL FERTILITY AND CULTIVATION

17. Organic Cultivation
Biological agriculture
The health of the topsoil is the most important factor in sustainable
agriculture. Topsoil is created by decayed vegetable matter, and can
vary in depth from a few centimetres to several metres. Forests created the deep soils of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> over millennia, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> of these
have shrunk by as <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> as 80% in the last <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> hundred <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span>
through our disastrous agricultural practices.
Under natural conditions the friable soil is populated with an
abundance of earthworms and other creatures and is usually
capped with a layer of humus, formed of decomposing leaves and
other vegetable matter, and colonized by a profusion of microbial
and creepy-crawly life. This rich mixture of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> forms makes up a
processing factory essential to soil health and fertility, and everything should be done to help it flourish.

Soil remineralization
In 1894 an agricultural chemist and contemporary of Justus von
Liebig, Julius Hensel, published Bread from Stone, a valuable <span class="t25 hoverable">book</span>
describing the beneficial effects of fertilizing with rock dust, a byproduct of road metal quarries. His book, posing a significant threat
to this <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> chemical fertilizer industry, quickly disappeared,
bought up and killed off by those who felt challenged by it.
Ideally ground in a cold process that retains its inherent energies, this rock dust in composed of finely ground, mainly igneous
rocks (such as granite, basalt, etc.) with a broad mineral spectrum.
Because of its <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> range of minerals, trace elements and salts,
when spread on the ground, it encourages a wealth of <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span>
micro-organisms.
There has been limited use of rock dust in Switzerland for 150
years. However, its reintroduction has been encouraged by John
Hamaker and Don Weaver who in 1975 <span class="t2 t4 t5 t22 t23 hoverable">brought</span> out The Survival of
Civilization.1 They describe how important are mineral and trace
elements to plant growth and quality, but <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> that trace elements
17. ORGANIC CULTIVATION

are a vital moderator of climatic extremes. They <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> tell how John
Hamaker was able to increase the depth of the topsoil at his Michigan home, from about 10cm (4in) to about 1.2m (4ft) over a period
of 10 years.
More recently in Western Australia, an experiment by Barry Oldfield for the 'Men of the Trees' showed a remarkable increase in the
growth and health of seedlings planted with rock dust compared
with those without. Rock dust is easily available as a by-product of
road metal quarries.
An initial application of very fine rock dust will quickly attract
micro-organisms, but a mixture of small and large grains will allow
a slow release over a longer period. Rock dust has been shown to be
a buffer against nitrate, sulphur dioxide and nitroxide, and it
absorbs and fixes the negative ions while saving the positive ions
for the plants' use. Normally rock dust is applied about <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">every</span> five
years, the quantity depending on soil deficiency, although it is
always beneficial.2
It is <span class="t0 t5 t6 t14 t18 hoverable">thought</span> that the remarkable longevity (up to 140 years) and
health of the Hunza <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> of Northern Pakistan is as <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> due to
the mineral-rich glacial water, as to the clean mountain air. Callum
Coats tells of his neighbours in Queensland who fertilized their fruit
trees from a bucket of rock dust. Their dogs, who <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> eagerly
drink rainwater from this bucket, while leaving their usual <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span>
bowls full, clearly knew what was best for them.

Organic farming
Organic farming normally uses manure (generally cow's), farmyard
slurry and composted vegetable matter to increase the soil's fertility. The introduction of chemical fertilizers in the nineteenth century was popular and soon supplanted the traditional organic
method, because it was <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> less labour intensive, and appeared to
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">give</span> higher crop yields. A few farmers retained the traditional methods and, as the evidence has built up of the pollution of the <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span>
table and rivers by these chemicals, there has been a renaissance of
organic farming in the last fifty years.
The sustainability of organic farming derives from the recycling
of organic material to maintain its fertility, just as in a natural forest. Modern organic composting tends to use green vegetable matter rather than dried, interleaved with layers of earth. Significant

heat is generated in the pile in this way. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Though</span> the compost <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span>
seem to be of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> quality, Viktor Schauberger believed that as the
heat discourages earthworms, it will not be of the best quality. His
preference is a cold process that produces a higher content of protein and other immaterial, fructigenic energies. He <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> believed it
important to protect the compost from element-hungry juvenile
rainwater that will tend to leach out some of the nutrients.
Although shown here on a small scale, the same principle can be
applied to larger compost heaps. Schauberger preferred an eggshaped compost heap built up under a large fruit-tree with a broad
canopy as shown in Fig. 17.1.
A hollow is dug out of the ground round the base of the tree <span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whose</span>
trunk is then wrapped loosely with several layers of newspaper, which
17. ORGANIC CULTIVATION

Fig. 17.1. The egg-shaped compost heap.

not only protect the tree but, once decomposed, provide an air duct
for ventilation. Into the hollow is placed a 20cm thick layer of Sundried leafmould and vegetable matter. This is covered with an equally
thick mixture of earth, river gravel and fine sand. This is similar to
remineralization, just described. A small amount of copper and zinc
filings is added to this mixture (see p. 232).
To stop the compost heap getting wet, it is then temporarily covered with clay or some other waterproof material. Insects, earthworms, and micro-organisms are quickly attracted into the heap
because it is a cool process. Helped by the diffused oxygen, nitrogen
and other trace gases penetrating the newspaper round the trunk
and the layer of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> and sand, they begin to break down the
refuse.
The heap is built up into the stable shape of the egg shown in
Fig. 17.1, as more vegetable refuse becomes available. To protect the
cold decomposition from being spoiled by rain, the finished heap
is then coated with a layer of clay. Any rain will run down the near
vertical surfaces.
The earthworms and microbes will now have multiplied in their
thousands through the <span class="t3 t5 t7 t9 t20 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> pile and aerated it. As they will begin
to die off, their bodies add nutritive value to the compost heap, having by now infiltrated the <span class="t3 t5 t7 t9 t20 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> of the compost heap. As the autumn
<span class="t0 t8 t11 t14 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">Sun</span> loses its strength, the ground starts to cool and a significant
positive temperature gradient is established between the ground
and the air. The compost heap is now ready; it is <span class="t19 hoverable">taken</span> down to
ground level, and what remains in the cavity is left to nourish the
tree.
The material is spread evenly over adjacent fields towards
evening, for under the positive temperature gradient — most powerful at this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> — rain or dew will carry the nutrients into the
ground. This method produces a <span class="t6 t9 t18 t26 hoverable">far</span> richer and higher-quality natural fertilizer, which not only maintains, but actually increases fertility. The host tree <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> benefits and will produce a copious crop of
healthy, tasty and blight-free fruit. Such compost heaps <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> be
built under <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> trees each year, eventually fertilizing all the
fruit trees. If there are no suitable trees, similarly constructed
heaps can be built as dome-like humps or barrel-shaped clumps,
protected from rainwater and insulated from the heating effect of
the Sun.

Biodynamic farming
Dr Rudolf Steiner (1861-1925), a teacher and philosopher born in
Austria, and founder of the Anthroposophical Movement, devised
biodynamic farming. <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">According</span> to anthroposophy the <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> being
is the <span class="t6 t9 t22 t29 hoverable">highest</span> expression on <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Earth</span> of the Divine, incarnating all creative <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> and patterns of physical manifestation. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> is
studied through the inner and outer natures of humanity. Its
approach to farming is very similar to Schauberger's, the assumption
that energy is the primary cause, and growth the secondary effect.
While it has been mooted that Rudolf Steiner and Viktor
Schauberger did have fairly lengthy discussions, if such was the case,
it is not clear how <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> either <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t18 t21 t22 t23 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">might</span> have influenced the other.
Biodynamic farming recognizes the very ancient practice of
burying cow's horns filled with cow dung deep underground in the
autumn. At this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> the active Earth's energies are drawn into the
horn because of its vortex shape, transforming its contents into
powerful fructigenic energies by the cold process of fermentation
encouraged by the low temperatures. The cow horns are disinterred
in early spring, their contents having been converted into a sweet
smelling, highly active substance.
This empowered material is the basis of the natural fertilizer
<span class="t6 t10 t15 hoverable">known</span> as '500 mix.' Since 1947, it has been increasing widely used,
and over a 1 1/4 million acres are fertilized in Australia using this system. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 hoverable">land</span> where it has been spread, when seen from the air,
stands out clearly from neighbouring farms, due to the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span>
greener pasture. Some cows from farms bordering Alex Podolinsky's did not eat for <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> <span class="t0 t3 t4 t5 t11 t20 t26 t27 hoverable">days</span> after they had broken into the
biodynamic farm, so high was the quality of the grass they had consumed.3
The '500' mix fertilizer is produced <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">according</span> to an ancient
Alpine tradition which Schauberger himself once observed being
practised by an <span class="t25 hoverable">old</span> mountain farmer who achieved amazing
results from his fertilizer. The principle is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> that of homeopathy.
When a homeopathic medicine is made, the original remedy is
stirred and shaken between the dilutions, which increase its
potency. With the fertilizer a small quantity of the converted cow
dung is added to <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> and stirred <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> direction and then
in the other, so as to create vortices rotating about the vertical axis

of the mixing vessel. A left-hand vortex builds up the positive

This method of progressively raising energy is analogous to the
Japanese art of sword making. The base material is heated in the
furnace, and then beaten out or 'structured' with a hammer as it
cools. It is then further heated to incandescence, folded over on
itself, fused <span class="t16 t21 hoverable">together</span> and beaten out again. Each <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> the heating

with repetition, the structure is cumulatively enhanced and the level
of chaos is diminished, ultimately producing a razor-sharp blade

vortices are alternately formed and destroyed in making the fertilizer, the level of energy rises and the degree of chaos decreases until,
after about an hour, the product is ready for use. This is sprayed on
the fields towards evening <span class="t5 t7 hoverable">within</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> hours of preparation
and before the accumulated energies have dispersed.
In <span class="t0 t6 t7 t8 t11 t13 t14 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">order</span> to produce larger quantities of the 500 mix, motor
driven paddles are <span class="t27 hoverable">used</span> in cylindrical vessels. Viktor's son, Walter,
<span class="t0 t16 t25 t28 hoverable">found</span> that the energies build up more strongly in an egg-shaped
vessel, and he devised <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> (Fig. 17.2) using a simple blade <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> a
gold golf club head as an impeller to infuse carbon-dioxide permanently into <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> under a partial vacuum.4
The farmer that Viktor watched <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> sang into the brew, rising
tones as he stirred to the left and falling tones as he stirred to the
right, adding crumbling pieces of aluminium-bearing clay into the
water. The chanting builds up creative energy in the water's memory (see p. 108, homeopathy). After about an hour the mixture was
ready to be spread over the fields. The following morning he did this
by dipping a branch with small leaves into the barrel and then flicking the energized clay-water emulsion over the ground, rather <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span>
<span class="t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t15 t19 t20 t23 t25 hoverable">holy</span> <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> is sprinkled with palm fronds on Palm Sunday.
Viktor Schauberger's methods of producing natural fertilizer
were similar to Rudolf Steiner's biodynamics, but they did not
depend on the thousands of cow horns <span class="t27 hoverable">used</span> by Podolinsky, which
are available now only because of the high demand for beef. Ultimately such a supply is non-sustainable, when you consider that in
